_publicationTitle: Complex splicing pattern generates great diversity in human NF1 transcripts.
details: Secondary structure predictions showed inconsistent correlation with exon skipping events, with some structures showing remarkable alterations while others did not
contextSnippet: Some structures showed remarkable alterations between both energy states, but many others did not at all...These data indicate that one has to be extremely careful when correlating exon skipping events to secondary structure predictions

_publicationTitle: Identification of hair shaft progenitors that create a niche for hair pigmentation.
details: All Scf(flox/gfp);Krox20Cre mice (n=20) displayed progressive hair graying with first round occurring homogenously during postnatal days 30-40, converting all black pigmented hairs to white within 9 months
contextSnippet: Invariably, all Scf mice (flox/gfp;Krox20Cre n = 20) displayed progressive hair graying. The first round of hair graying occurred homogenously during postnatal days 30–40 (P30–P40).

_publicationTitle: Identification of hair shaft progenitors that create a niche for hair pigmentation.
details: Krox20 lineage cells showed dynamic localization during HF morphogenesis, detected only in infundibulum and bulge at P0, expanding to entire upper HF at P2, then colonizing matrix beginning at P6-P10
contextSnippet: we found that LacZ+ cells were detected only as a small population of cells located at the infundibulum and bulge of the HF at P0. At P2, LacZ+ cells occupied the entire upper portion of the HF.

_publicationTitle: Identification of hair shaft progenitors that create a niche for hair pigmentation.
details: Scf(flox/gfp);K14Cre mice displayed complete absence of hair pigmentation beginning at birth, lasting throughout their lives (n=8)
contextSnippet: Strikingly, depletion of SCF in keratinocytes resulted in mice displaying a complete absence of hair pigmentation, beginning at birth (Fig. 2 F), and this phenotype was limited to hair pigmentation

_publicationTitle: Identification of hair shaft progenitors that create a niche for hair pigmentation.
details: Scf(flox/gfp);DhhCre mice showed no hair color changes for up to 6 months (n=8), demonstrating hair pigmentation does not depend on SCF expression in Schwann cells
contextSnippet: In mice lacking SCF in Schwann cells (Scf flox/gfp;DhhCre), we did not observe any hair color changes for up to 6 mo (Fig. 2 A). n = 8.

_publicationTitle: Identification of hair shaft progenitors that create a niche for hair pigmentation.

contextSnippet: mice with SCF depletion in melanocytes (Scf flox/gfp;TyrCreERT2) had no phenotype in hair color (Fig. 2 C) after validation of Cre expression in the hair matrix melanocytes

_publicationTitle: Identification of hair shaft progenitors that create a niche for hair pigmentation.

contextSnippet: Surprisingly, the K14-Scf;Scf flox/gfp;K14Cre mice displayed white hair with dark skin (Fig. 4 A,B), indicating that even though Scf is expressed under a K14 promoter, K14-Scf was unable to rescue

_publicationTitle: A bioinspired gelatin-hyaluronic acid-based hybrid interpenetrating network for the enhancement of retinal ganglion cells replacement therapy.
details: IPN reduced viability drop by protecting cells from lack of nutrients, maintaining 35-45% viability after 1 week of medium deprivation compared to <7% for PBS
contextSnippet: when cells received no nutrients viability decreased significantly with time, reaching <7% for the PBS sample after 7 days. Notably, IPN reduced this drop of viability by protecting the cells from the lack of nutrients for all time points, being significantly higher for all IPN groups compared to PBS samples (35–45% viable after 1 week of medium deprivation).

_publicationTitle: Cognitive and Electrophysiological Correlates of Working Memory Impairments in Neurofibromatosis Type 1.
details: P300 amplitude was larger for 1-back (M = 14.002 uV, SEM = 1.057) than for 2-back (M = 11.497 uV, SEM = 0.967), with no significant group differences between NF1 and controls
contextSnippet: In the 2 × 2 Group x N-back mixed ANCOVA on P300 amplitude, a main effect of N-back was found, F (1,28) = 11.077, p = 0.002, η p = 0.283 – amplitude was larger for 1-back (M = 14.002 uV, SEM = 1.057) than for 2-back (M = 11.497 uV, SEM = 0.967). Neither the main effect of Group (F < 1, p > 0.8) nor the Group x N-back interaction (F (1,28) = 1.115, p = 0.300) was significant.

_publicationTitle: Cognitive and Electrophysiological Correlates of Working Memory Impairments in Neurofibromatosis Type 1.
details: P300 latency was significantly shorter in NF1 (M = 485.16 ms, SEM = 10.83) than in controls (M = 522.83 ms, SEM = 11.19), with group difference significant in 2-back task (difference M = 54.917 ms, p = 0.004)
contextSnippet: A main effect of Group was found, F (1,28) = 6.788, p = 0.015, η p = 0.195 with shorter latencies in NF1 (M = 485.16 ms, SEM = 10.83) than in Controls (M = 522.83 ms, SEM = 11.19). This group effect was modulated by a significant Group x N-back interaction, F (1,29) = 5.794, p = 0.023, η p = 0.171. The group difference in latencies was significant in the 2-back task (t (29) = 3.082, p = 0.004, difference M = 54.917 ms, SEM = 17.820)

_publicationTitle: Cognitive and Electrophysiological Correlates of Working Memory Impairments in Neurofibromatosis Type 1.
details: NF1 group showed topographic differences including reduced left frontal activity in late time-window and greater parietal positivity in 2-back task compared to controls
contextSnippet: The NF1 group showed stronger right frontal positivity in the early time window, but weaker left frontal positivity in the late time-window, particularly when the difference between target and non-target P300s was considered. Further, in the 2-back task, the NF1 group showed a stronger mid-to-left parietal positivity

_publicationTitle: Cognitive and Electrophysiological Correlates of Working Memory Impairments in Neurofibromatosis Type 1.
details: In NF1 group, Sky Search selective attention measure was negatively correlated with P300 amplitude difference in late time-window 2-back task and negatively correlated with 2-back P300 latency
contextSnippet: In the NF1 group, Sky Search, a measure of selective attention, was negatively correlated with P300 amplitude difference (Target – Non-target) in the late time-window in the 2-back task, in both left parietal and left frontal (the latter only marginally) regions. Sky Search was also negatively correlated with 2-back P300 latency in NF1 (only)

_publicationTitle: Cognitive and Electrophysiological Correlates of Working Memory Impairments in Neurofibromatosis Type 1.

contextSnippet: several adaptive function-P300 amplitude relationships were found to show a significant non-linear, inverted-U relationship in the NF1 group: late time-window left frontal activity in both 1- and 2-back blocks. This pattern suggests that NF1 individuals with mid-range adaptive function are able to engage this compensatory mechanism

_publicationTitle: Quality of life in individuals with neurofibromatosis type 1 associated cutaneous neurofibromas: validation of the Dutch cNF-Skindex.
details: Mean total cNF-Skindex score was 40.7 (SD 27.1) with median 36.0 (IQR 15.0-65.0) and score range 3-94
contextSnippet: The mean total cNF-Skindex score was 40.7 (Table 2). Nine participants had a total cNF-Skindex score that placed them in severity stratum 1 (nonbothersome cNF, 15%), 28 were in stratum 2 (moderately bothersome cNF, 48%) and 22 patients were in stratum 3 (very bothersome cNF, 37%).

_publicationTitle: Quality of life in individuals with neurofibromatosis type 1 associated cutaneous neurofibromas: validation of the Dutch cNF-Skindex.
details: High internal consistency with Cronbach's alpha above 0.90 for total score (0.96) and all subdomains (Functioning: 0.93, Emotions: 0.93, Symptoms: 0.91)
contextSnippet: The Cronbach's alpha of the total score and the subdomains were all above 0.90, indicating high internal consistency.

_publicationTitle: Quality of life in individuals with neurofibromatosis type 1 associated cutaneous neurofibromas: validation of the Dutch cNF-Skindex.
details: Adequate test-retest reliability with Spearman's correlation r=0.88 for total score, r=0.89 for Functioning, r=0.83 for Emotions, and r=0.85 for Symptoms (all p<0.001)
contextSnippet: Adequate test-retest reliability was observed for both the total cNF-Skindex score (Spearman's correlation r = 0.88), the 'Functioning' subdomain (r = 0.89), 'Emotions' subdomain (r = 0.83), and 'Symptoms' subdomain (r = 0.85), with all p-values < 0.001.

_publicationTitle: Quality of life in individuals with neurofibromatosis type 1 associated cutaneous neurofibromas: validation of the Dutch cNF-Skindex.
details: Significant differences in scores between participants with ≤50 cNF vs >50 cNF (27.9 vs 45.4, p=0.017) and between those with vs without cNF-related intervention (30.5 vs 47.7, p=0.026)
contextSnippet: For known-group validity, significant differences in cNF-Skindex scores were observed between participants with ≤ 50 cNF or more than 50 cNF, as well as for participants who had and who had not received a cNF-related intervention

_publicationTitle: Quality of life in individuals with neurofibromatosis type 1 associated cutaneous neurofibromas: validation of the Dutch cNF-Skindex.
details: Mean Spearman correlation with cNF-Skindex total score was 0.30 (range 0.07-0.358, p-values 0.005-0.606). VAS correlation with cNF-Skindex was -0.32 (p=0.012)
contextSnippet: Regarding convergent validity, the mean Spearman correlation between the total cNF-Skindex score and the items of the EQ-5D-5L was 0.30 (correlations ranging between 0.07 and 0.358, with p-values ranging between 0.005 and 0.606) The Spearman correlation between the total cNF-Skindex score and the EQ-5D-5L VAS was − 0.32 (p-value = 0.012).

_publicationTitle: Quality of life in individuals with neurofibromatosis type 1 associated cutaneous neurofibromas: validation of the Dutch cNF-Skindex.
details: Total and subdomain scores of cNF-Skindex correlated significantly with several SF-36 scales
contextSnippet: The total and subdomain scores of the cNF-Skindex score also correlated significantly with several of the SF-36 scales (ANNEX 1).

_publicationTitle: Quality of life in individuals with neurofibromatosis type 1 associated cutaneous neurofibromas: validation of the Dutch cNF-Skindex.
details: Kaiser-Meyer-Olkin test verified sampling adequacy with KMO of 0.89. Three factors explained 76.4% of total variance in exploratory factor analysis
contextSnippet: The Kaiser–Meyer–Olkin test verified the sampling adequacy for the analysis, with a KMO of 0.89. The scree plot showed an inflexion that justified the selection of three factors. The three identified factors ('Functioning', 'Symptoms', and 'Emotions') explained 76.4% of the total variance

_publicationTitle: In vivo functional analysis of the human NF2 tumor suppressor gene in Drosophila.
details: Hemizygous null allele severely truncates the Merlin protein and causes lethality that can be rescued by NF2 transgenes
contextSnippet: Ability to rescue was tested using ubiquitous expression via the Gal4/UAS system in animals hemizygous for the Mer4 null allele, which severely truncates the Merlin protein

_publicationTitle: In vivo functional analysis of the human NF2 tumor suppressor gene in Drosophila.
details: NF2 Iso1 provided 59±7% rescue at 1 dose and 72% rescue at 2 doses; NF2 Iso2 provided 8±4% rescue at 1 dose and 0% rescue at 2 doses
contextSnippet: expression of a transgene expressing NF2Iso1 using the ubiquitously expressed T80 Gal4 driver substantially rescued the lethality of the null Mer4 allele, while NF2Iso2 provided very poor rescue

_publicationTitle: In vivo functional analysis of the human NF2 tumor suppressor gene in Drosophila.
details: Successfully detected Flag-tagged NF2 proteins in immunostaining experiments to confirm expression of all NF2 forms
contextSnippet: immunostaining using anti-Flag antibody (Fig. 2) and immunoblot analysis (data not shown) were used to confirm expression of all NF2 forms

_publicationTitle: In vivo functional analysis of the human NF2 tumor suppressor gene in Drosophila.
details: Specifically recognized Drosophila Merlin protein without cross-reacting with human Merlin, allowing detection of endogenous Merlin changes upon NF2 expression
contextSnippet: our anti-Drosophila Merlin antiserum (raised against the less conserved carboxyl terminal half of the protein) specifically recognized the fly protein and did not cross react with human Merlin

_publicationTitle: In vivo functional analysis of the human NF2 tumor suppressor gene in Drosophila.
details: Enabled tissue-specific expression in dorsal wing compartment, revealing dominant negative effects of NF2 Iso2 including wing cupping phenotype characteristic of overproliferation
contextSnippet: we observed a marked downward 'cupping' of the wing blade when NF2Iso2 was expressed in the dorsal half of the wing. This phenotype is characteristic of overproliferation in the dorsal wing compartment

_publicationTitle: In vivo functional analysis of the human NF2 tumor suppressor gene in Drosophila.
details: Used for confocal microscopy to analyze subcellular localization patterns of NF2 proteins in wing imaginal epithelia
contextSnippet: Confocal optical sections of wing imaginal epithelia, either cutting deeply into the epithelium ('Cross section') or tangentially through the apical surface

_publicationTitle: In vivo functional analysis of the human NF2 tumor suppressor gene in Drosophila.
details: Used for confocal microscopy to demonstrate temperature-sensitive mislocalization of NF2 L64P protein at 37°C versus normal localization at 25°C
contextSnippet: the punctate apical staining that is characteristic of NF2Iso1 was disrupted when animals expressing the NF2L64P protein were maintained at 37°C for two hours, and instead the mutant protein appeared largely cytoplasmic

_publicationTitle: In vivo functional analysis of the human NF2 tumor suppressor gene in Drosophila.
details: qPCR analysis showed no detectable effect of NF2 expression on endogenous Merlin transcription levels, indicating posttranscriptional effects
contextSnippet: quantitative PCR analysis failed to show any detectable effect on Merlin transcription in wing imaginal discs expressing either NF2 isoform under the apGal4 driver

_publicationTitle: Mass spectrometric insights into the protein composition of human cutaneous neurofibromas: comparison of neurofibromas with the overlying skin.
details: 2.21-fold (95% CI 1.69 to 2.88, P < 0.001) expression in cNFs compared to skin, confirming successful dissection of cNF tissue from overlying skin
contextSnippet: The successful dissection of the cNF tissue from the overlying skin was confirmed by the 2.21-fold (95% CI 1.69 to 2.88, P < 0.001) expression of the Schwann cell marker S100B in cNFs compared to skin.

_publicationTitle: Mass spectrometric insights into the protein composition of human cutaneous neurofibromas: comparison of neurofibromas with the overlying skin.
details: Few Ki67 positive cells were observed within cNFs, in contrast to numerous proliferating cells in the epidermis, confirming low rate of cell proliferation in cNFs
contextSnippet: The low rate of cell proliferation in cNFs was confirmed by the Ki67 immunolabeling of 20 cNFs. Few Ki67 positive cells were observed within cNFs, which is in contrast to the numerous proliferating cells in the epidermis

_publicationTitle: Mass spectrometric insights into the protein composition of human cutaneous neurofibromas: comparison of neurofibromas with the overlying skin.
details: Immunohistochemistry confirmed abundant expression of collagen XV in cNFs
contextSnippet: Immunohistochemistry confirmed the abundant expression of collagens XV and XVIII in cNFs

_publicationTitle: Mass spectrometric insights into the protein composition of human cutaneous neurofibromas: comparison of neurofibromas with the overlying skin.
details: Immunohistochemistry confirmed abundant expression of collagen XVIII in cNFs
contextSnippet: Immunohistochemistry confirmed the abundant expression of collagens XV and XVIII in cNFs

_publicationTitle: Mass spectrometric insights into the protein composition of human cutaneous neurofibromas: comparison of neurofibromas with the overlying skin.
details: Successfully performed mass spectrometry analysis of 15 cNFs and matched skin samples from four individuals with NF1, enabling protein composition comparison
contextSnippet: We performed mass spectrometry analysis of 15 cNFs and matched samples of the overlying skin from four individuals with NF1

_publicationTitle: Mass spectrometric insights into the protein composition of human cutaneous neurofibromas: comparison of neurofibromas with the overlying skin.
details: Used for data analysis in hierarchical clustering that showed incomplete separation between cNF and skin samples, with subclusters based on tissue type rather than patient emerging when samples were pooled
contextSnippet: When the samples from all individuals were pooled into a single analysis, subclusters based on tissue type rather than patient emerged, indicating tissue-specific patterns of protein expression shared by multiple individuals. However, the separation was incomplete.

_publicationTitle: NF1 heterozygosity fosters de novo tumorigenesis but impairs malignant transformation.

_publicationTitle: NF1 heterozygosity fosters de novo tumorigenesis but impairs malignant transformation.

contextSnippet: Overall, we did not identify any skin phenotype in K14 Cre; Nf1 f/f mice

contextSnippet: At one year of age, the majority of PLP CreERT2; Nf1 f/− (77 out of 104, 74%) mice already developed pNF and showed the clinical signs of pNF, whereas only a minority of PLP CreERT2; Nf1 f/f (32 out of 112, 29%) mice did

_publicationTitle: NF1 heterozygosity fosters de novo tumorigenesis but impairs malignant transformation.
resourceName: PLP CreERT2; Nf1 f/−; ROSA-LacZ mice

contextSnippet: no MPNST developed in PLP CreERT2; Nf1 f/− mice (0 out of 104, 0%), whereas all MPNST observed arose from PLP CreERT2; Nf1 f/f mice (10%, 11 out of 112) (exact Fischer test value = 0.001)

_publicationTitle: NF1 heterozygosity fosters de novo tumorigenesis but impairs malignant transformation.

contextSnippet: immunohistochemistry using keratin 1 (K1, an epithelial cell marker that is lost upon cancer progression) antibodies confirmed the low expression of K1 in tumor samples from both Nf1 f/f and K14 Cre; Nf1 f/f mice

_publicationTitle: NF1 heterozygosity fosters de novo tumorigenesis but impairs malignant transformation.
details: K1 expression maintained only in tumors from Nf1 +/− mice but not in Nf1 +/+ mice tumors that progressed to SCC

_publicationTitle: NF1 heterozygosity fosters de novo tumorigenesis but impairs malignant transformation.

contextSnippet: We found that Nf1 +/− T cells are more hyperproliferative when stimulated with anti-CD3 than their wild-type counterparts

_publicationTitle: NF1 heterozygosity fosters de novo tumorigenesis but impairs malignant transformation.

_publicationTitle: NF1 heterozygosity fosters de novo tumorigenesis but impairs malignant transformation.

contextSnippet: qRT-PCR revealed a more than twofold increase of Mia expression in Nf1Prx1-deficient cartilage

_publicationTitle: MIA is a potential biomarker for tumour load in neurofibromatosis type 1.
details: More intensive Mia expression observed in NF1-deficient cartilage compared to controls
contextSnippet: The expression of Mia was found to be more intensive in the NF1-deficient cartilage of the Nf1Prx1 mice

_publicationTitle: MIA is a potential biomarker for tumour load in neurofibromatosis type 1.
details: Successfully detected MIA in NF1-associated tumors with 50-90% of cells showing positive staining
contextSnippet: MIA was immunohistochemically detected on the paraffin sections of six cutaneous and three plexiform neurofibromas and in seven MPNSTs from NF1 patients. The proportion of MIA-positive cells varied between 50% and 90%

_publicationTitle: MIA is a potential biomarker for tumour load in neurofibromatosis type 1.
details: Most intense staining obtained in MPNSTs due to high nuclear density

_publicationTitle: MIA is a potential biomarker for tumour load in neurofibromatosis type 1.
details: Detected significantly higher MIA serum concentration in NF1 patients versus healthy controls: 15.16 ± 1.26 pg/mL versus 4.54 ± 0.40 pg/mL (P < 0.001)
contextSnippet: MIA serum concentration was significantly higher in NF1 patients than in healthy controls: 15.16 ± 1.26 pg/mL versus 4.54 ± 0.40 pg/mL (P < 0.001)

_publicationTitle: MIA is a potential biomarker for tumour load in neurofibromatosis type 1.
details: Showed positive correlation between MIA serum level and internal tumor load with R² = ~0.64
contextSnippet: linear regression analysis revealed an association between the total internal tumour load and MIA serum level (P value of 1.95E-7 for the F-test). The line that best predicts MIA level from values of logarithm of internal tumor load volume was identified by regression analysis: R² = ~0.64

_publicationTitle: MIA is a potential biomarker for tumour load in neurofibromatosis type 1.

contextSnippet: We next quantified Mia expression by performing quantitative real-time polymerase chain reaction (qRT-PCR). qRT-PCR revealed a more than twofold increase of Mia expression in Nf1Prx1-deficient cartilage

_publicationTitle: MIA is a potential biomarker for tumour load in neurofibromatosis type 1.

contextSnippet: Absolute quantification was conducted on the RNA isolated from knee cartilage of two mutant and two control mice at P4. qRT-PCR revealed a more than twofold increase of Mia expression in Nf1Prx1-deficient cartilage

_publicationTitle: Microarray analyses reveal regional astrocyte heterogeneity with implications for neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1)-regulated glial proliferation.
details: Identified 1446 differential expressed genes (4.2% of total genes) from >39,000 transcripts representing ~34,000 mouse genes
contextSnippet: Using Affymetrix Mouse Genome 430 2.0 GeneChip microarrays containing >39,000 transcripts and variants representing ~34,000 mouse genes, a small set of 1446 differential expressed genes (4.2% of total genes) were identified.

_publicationTitle: Microarray analyses reveal regional astrocyte heterogeneity with implications for neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1)-regulated glial proliferation.
details: Greater than 98% of cells from CTX, CB, and BS astroglial cultures were GFAP+, while ~30% of ON cells expressed GFAP
contextSnippet: Greater than 98% of the cells from CTX, CB, and BS astroglial cultures were GFAP+...In contrast to astroglial cells from CB, CTX, and BS, ~30% of these cells expressed GFAP

_publicationTitle: Microarray analyses reveal regional astrocyte heterogeneity with implications for neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1)-regulated glial proliferation.
details: >83% of cells from CTX, CB, and BS cultures expressed aquaporin-4, while ~30% of ON cells expressed AQP4
contextSnippet: Similarly, >83% of the cells from these cultures expressed aquaporin-4 (AQP4)...In contrast to astroglial cells from CB, CTX, and BS, ~30% of these cells expressed GFAP, AQP4 or GLAST

_publicationTitle: Microarray analyses reveal regional astrocyte heterogeneity with implications for neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1)-regulated glial proliferation.
details: >83% of cells from CTX, CB, and BS cultures expressed GLAST, while ~30% of ON cells expressed GLAST
contextSnippet: Similarly, >83% of the cells from these cultures expressed aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and the astroglial glutamate transporter GLAST...In contrast to astroglial cells from CB, CTX, and BS, ~30% of these cells expressed GFAP, AQP4 or GLAST

_publicationTitle: Microarray analyses reveal regional astrocyte heterogeneity with implications for neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1)-regulated glial proliferation.
details: ~70% of ON cells expressed NG2 chondroitin sulphate proteoglycan with mutually exclusive expression of NG2 and GFAP
contextSnippet: Interestingly, ~70% of cells expressed the NG2 chondroitin sulphate proteoglycan...It is important to note that there was mutually exclusive expression of NG2 and GFAP in these astroglial cells

_publicationTitle: Microarray analyses reveal regional astrocyte heterogeneity with implications for neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1)-regulated glial proliferation.
details: O4-positive oligodendrocyte lineage cells were rarely detected and no expression found in ON astroglial cell cultures
contextSnippet: In contrast, O4- or APC-positive (oligodendrocyte lineage) cells were rarely detected...we examined the expression of two common OPC markers, O4 and APC, and found no expression of either O4 or APC in these ON astroglial cell cultures

_publicationTitle: Microarray analyses reveal regional astrocyte heterogeneity with implications for neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1)-regulated glial proliferation.
details: APC-positive oligodendrocyte lineage cells were rarely detected and no expression found in ON astroglial cell cultures
contextSnippet: In contrast, O4- or APC-positive (oligodendrocyte lineage) cells were rarely detected...we examined the expression of two common OPC markers, O4 and APC, and found no expression of either O4 or APC in these ON astroglial cell cultures

_publicationTitle: Microarray analyses reveal regional astrocyte heterogeneity with implications for neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1)-regulated glial proliferation.
details: >90% of ON astroglial cells expressed FOXP2 compared to <10% of astroglial cells from CTX, CB and BS
contextSnippet: In addition, FOXP2 immunocytochemistry revealed that >90% positive of ON astroglial cells expressed FOXP2 compared to <10% of the astroglial cells from CTX, CB and BS

_publicationTitle: Microarray analyses reveal regional astrocyte heterogeneity with implications for neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1)-regulated glial proliferation.
details: Western blot analysis demonstrated significantly lower levels of neurofibromin expression in CTX astroglial cells than in astroglial cells from other brain regions
contextSnippet: In addition, Western blot analysis also demonstrated significantly lower levels of neurofibromin expression in CTX astroglial cells than in astroglial cells from the other brain regions

_publicationTitle: Microarray analyses reveal regional astrocyte heterogeneity with implications for neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1)-regulated glial proliferation.
details: Neurofibromin levels were undetectable in astroglial cells infected with Ad5-Cre compared to Ad5-LacZ
contextSnippet: In all cases, neurofibromin levels were undetectable in astroglial cells infected with Ad5-Cre compared to Ad5-LacZ

_publicationTitle: Microarray analyses reveal regional astrocyte heterogeneity with implications for neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1)-regulated glial proliferation.
details: Nf1 inactivation resulted in ≥2-fold increase in proliferation of astroglial cells from CB, BS and ON, but no increase in CTX astroglial cells
contextSnippet: Using [3H]-thymidine incorporation, Nf1 inactivation resulted in ≥2-fold increase in proliferation of astroglial cells from CB, BS and ON. In contrast, no increase in proliferation was observed following Nf1 inactivation in CTX astroglial cells

_publicationTitle: Microarray analyses reveal regional astrocyte heterogeneity with implications for neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1)-regulated glial proliferation.
details: Nearly 2-fold increase in GFAP+ cells in BS and significant increase in CB, with 50% increase in NG2 staining in optic nerves, but no effect in CTX
contextSnippet: Whereas there was no effect of Nf1 loss on the number of GFAP+ cells in the CTX, we observed nearly a 2-fold increase in the number of GFAP+ cells in the BS...we detected a 50% increase in NG2 staining in the Nf1GFAP CKO mouse optic nerves

_publicationTitle: Microarray analyses reveal regional astrocyte heterogeneity with implications for neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1)-regulated glial proliferation.
details: Increased numbers of Ki-67-immunoreactive cells observed in CB, BS and ON of Nf1GFAP CKO mice, but not in CTX
contextSnippet: Consistent with in vitro proliferation results, we observed increased numbers of Ki-67-immunoreactive cells in CB, BS and ON of Nf1GFAP CKO mice, but not in the CTX

_publicationTitle: Integrating Functional Analysis in the Next-Generation Sequencing Diagnostic Pipeline of RASopathies.

_publicationTitle: STING activation reprograms the microenvironment to sensitize NF1-related malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumors for immunotherapy.
details: Developed MPNSTs between 3 and 7 months of age as a result of spontaneous loss of WT Nf1 and p53 alleles
contextSnippet: As a result of spontaneous loss of the WT Nf1 and p53 alleles, cisNf1 +/– p53 (hereafter referred to as +/– cisNP) mice develop a variety of sarcomas including MPNST (cis MPNST) between 3 and 7 months of age.

_publicationTitle: STING activation reprograms the microenvironment to sensitize NF1-related malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumors for immunotherapy.
details: cis MPNSTs were cold tumors containing few T cells (CD3+, CD4+, CD8α+) and few B cells (CD20+) compared with spleen and pNFs
contextSnippet: we found that cis MPNSTs contained few T cells (including CD3+ T cells, CD4+ T helper [Th] cells, and CD8α+ cytotoxic T cells) (Figure 1A) and few B cells (CD20+) (Figure 1B) compared with spleen and pNFs.

_publicationTitle: STING activation reprograms the microenvironment to sensitize NF1-related malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumors for immunotherapy.
details: MPNSTs in athymic nude mice were negative for CD3, CD4, and CD8α expression as expected since nude mice lack T cells
contextSnippet: MPNSTs that developed in allograft mice, in which MPNST cells were harvested from cisNP mice and implanted into athymic nude mouse hosts, were also negative for CD3, CD4, and CD8α expression

_publicationTitle: STING activation reprograms the microenvironment to sensitize NF1-related malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumors for immunotherapy.
details: Allograft cis MPNSTs in athymic mice continued to grow despite ADU-S100 treatment, suggesting immune inflammation from STING activation was mediated by T cells
contextSnippet: These allograft cis MPNSTs in athymic mice continued to grow despite ADU-S100 treatment (Supplemental Figure 4, B and C), suggesting that the immune inflammation resulting from STING activation was mediated by T cells

_publicationTitle: STING activation reprograms the microenvironment to sensitize NF1-related malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumors for immunotherapy.
details: Showed increased expression of phosphorylated IRF (p-IRF) and p–NF-ĸB after 8 hours of ADU-S100 treatment, indicating STING pathway activation
contextSnippet: Western blot analysis, which showed increased expression of phosphorylated IRF (p-IRF) and p–NF-ĸB, indicating STING pathway activation after 8 hours of ADU-S100 treatment

_publicationTitle: STING activation reprograms the microenvironment to sensitize NF1-related malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumors for immunotherapy.
details: Showed increased expression of phosphorylated IRF (p-IRF) and p–NF-ĸB after 8 hours of ADU-S100 treatment, indicating STING pathway activation
contextSnippet: We first tested ADU-S100 on 2 different MPNST cell lines: a mouse MPNST cell line derived from Nf1- and p53-null skin progenitor cells (HTS-Luc MPNST) and cis MPNST cells derived from cisNP mice.

_publicationTitle: STING activation reprograms the microenvironment to sensitize NF1-related malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumors for immunotherapy.
details: Activated STING pathway with highest expression of cytokine/chemokine genes 8 hours after treatment in MPNST cells
contextSnippet: Quantitative reverse transcription real-time PCR (qRT-PCR) had the highest expression of cytokine/chemokine genes 8 hours after ADU-S100 treatment (Supplemental Figure 1D), demonstrating that ADU-S100 treatment could activate STING/IFN signaling

_publicationTitle: STING activation reprograms the microenvironment to sensitize NF1-related malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumors for immunotherapy.
details: Upregulated markers of STING pathway activation (p-IRF3 and p–NF-ĸB) and proinflammatory cytokines/chemokines (Ifnb1, Tnf, Cxcl10, Il12a) in vivo
contextSnippet: We observed that markers of STING pathway activation such as p-IRF3 and p–NF-ĸB were indeed upregulated in both the ADU-S100– and SA3-treated tumors compared with vehicle controls

_publicationTitle: STING activation reprograms the microenvironment to sensitize NF1-related malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumors for immunotherapy.
details: Increased infiltration of CD3+ T cells, CD4+ Th cells, CD8+ cytotoxic T cells, and PD-1–expressing cells into tumors
contextSnippet: IHC revealed that treatment with the STING agonists increased infiltration of CD3+ T cells, CD4+ Th cells, and CD8+ cytotoxic T cells, as well as PD-1–expressing cells, into the tumor

_publicationTitle: STING activation reprograms the microenvironment to sensitize NF1-related malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumors for immunotherapy.
details: Treatment alone resulted in slower tumor growth but did not cause complete regression of tumors
contextSnippet: We found that treatment with either ADU-S100 alone or SA3 alone resulted in slower tumor growth, indicating that STING activation and subsequent recruitment of immune cells to the tumor can impede tumor growth

_publicationTitle: STING activation reprograms the microenvironment to sensitize NF1-related malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumors for immunotherapy.
details: Significantly slowed MPNST growth in cisNP mice (P = 0.0123 for percentage increase in tumor volume vs control)
contextSnippet: we found that the STING agonist alone was able to significantly slow MPNST growth in our cisNP mice (percentage increase in tumor volume for control vs. ADU-S100 treatment, P = 0.0123

_publicationTitle: STING activation reprograms the microenvironment to sensitize NF1-related malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumors for immunotherapy.
details: Upregulated markers of STING pathway activation (p-IRF3 and p–NF-ĸB) and proinflammatory cytokines/chemokines when administered intraperitoneally
contextSnippet: We observed that markers of STING pathway activation such as p-IRF3 and p–NF-ĸB were indeed upregulated in both the ADU-S100– and SA3-treated tumors compared with vehicle controls

_publicationTitle: STING activation reprograms the microenvironment to sensitize NF1-related malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumors for immunotherapy.
details: Treatment alone resulted in slower tumor growth and significantly slowed MPNST growth (P = 0.0384 for percentage increase in tumor volume vs control)
contextSnippet: We found that treatment with either ADU-S100 alone or SA3 alone resulted in slower tumor growth

_publicationTitle: STING activation reprograms the microenvironment to sensitize NF1-related malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumors for immunotherapy.
details: Combination with ADU-S100 resulted in smaller tumors compared to vehicle treatment and significantly increased apoptotic cell death compared to ADU-S100 alone
contextSnippet: MPNSTs that received the combination treatment of ADU-S100 plus anti–PD-1 showed significantly increased apoptotic cell death compared with those treated with ADU-S100 alone

_publicationTitle: STING activation reprograms the microenvironment to sensitize NF1-related malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumors for immunotherapy.
details: In xenograft model, combination with ADU-S100 caused complete tumor regression more quickly than ADU-S100 alone, with tumors significantly smaller by day 14
contextSnippet: by day 14, tumors that received the combination treatment were significantly smaller than the tumors treated with ADU-S100 alone and completely regressed more quickly than their ADU-S100–treated counterparts

_publicationTitle: Late morbidity and mortality in adult survivors of childhood glioma with neurofibromatosis type 1: report from the Childhood Cancer Survivor Study.

contextSnippet: Survivors of childhood glioma with NF1 who were adults at the time of evaluation had an increased risk of global distress (relative risk [95%CI]: 2.48 [1.25–4.91]) as well as depression (1.94 [1.01–3.76]), anxiety (3.22 [1.60–6.47]) and somatization (2.07 [1.05–4.09])

_publicationTitle: Late morbidity and mortality in adult survivors of childhood glioma with neurofibromatosis type 1: report from the Childhood Cancer Survivor Study.

_publicationTitle: Late morbidity and mortality in adult survivors of childhood glioma with neurofibromatosis type 1: report from the Childhood Cancer Survivor Study.

contextSnippet: Compared to siblings, glioma survivors with NF1 showed an increased risk of emotional impairment on both the BSI-18 (all domains) and the BPI (peer conflict)

_publicationTitle: Late morbidity and mortality in adult survivors of childhood glioma with neurofibromatosis type 1: report from the Childhood Cancer Survivor Study.
details: Glioma survivors with NF1 had significantly increased risk of impairment in all neurocognitive domains compared to siblings, and increased risk of impaired task completion (1.50 [1.14-1.96]) compared to glioma survivors without NF1
contextSnippet: Compared to siblings, glioma survivors with NF1 had significantly increased risk of impairment in all neurocognitive domains, and increased risk of impaired task completion (1.50 [1.14–1.96]) compared to glioma survivors without NF1

_publicationTitle: Late morbidity and mortality in adult survivors of childhood glioma with neurofibromatosis type 1: report from the Childhood Cancer Survivor Study.
resourceName: Common Terminology Criteria for Adverse Events, version 4.0 (CTCAE v4.0)
details: CTCAE grade 3-4 chronic health conditions diagnosed before study entry were more prevalent in glioma survivors with NF1 (46.3% [38.1%-54.4%]) vs without NF1 (30.8% [29.1%-32.6%]), p<0.001
contextSnippet: Compared to survivors without NF1, CTCAE grade 3–4 chronic health conditions diagnosed before study entry (5 years after diagnosis) were more prevalent in glioma survivors with NF1 (46.3% [38.1%−54.4] vs. 30.8% [29.1%−32.6%], p<0.001

_publicationTitle: Late morbidity and mortality in adult survivors of childhood glioma with neurofibromatosis type 1: report from the Childhood Cancer Survivor Study.
resourceName: Common Terminology Criteria for Adverse Events, version 4.0 (CTCAE v4.0)

_publicationTitle: SVA retrotransposon insertion-associated deletion represents a novel mutational mechanism underlying large genomic copy number changes with non-recurrent breakpoints.

contextSnippet: Breakpoint-spanning PCRs, using the Expand Long Template PCR system under standard conditions with primers designed on the basis of the array CGH results, were successful in the case of 15 of the 17 atypical NF1 deletions

_publicationTitle: SVA retrotransposon insertion-associated deletion represents a novel mutational mechanism underlying large genomic copy number changes with non-recurrent breakpoints.

contextSnippet: GenomeWalker analysis of the breakpoint regions in this patient then revealed the insertion of an SINE/VNTR/Alu (SVA) retrotransposon, which is absent from the human genome reference sequence (hg19), at the corresponding genomic position

_publicationTitle: SVA retrotransposon insertion-associated deletion represents a novel mutational mechanism underlying large genomic copy number changes with non-recurrent breakpoints.

_publicationTitle: SVA retrotransposon insertion-associated deletion represents a novel mutational mechanism underlying large genomic copy number changes with non-recurrent breakpoints.

_publicationTitle: PET Imaging of Neurofibromatosis Type 1 with a Fluorine-18 Labeled Tryptophan Radiotracer.
resourceName: Trp53, Nf1, Suz12 triple mutant mice
details: Highest L-[18F]FETrp uptake in pancreas at 5 min (15.8 ± 1.6 ID%/g), increased at 30 min (24.4 ± 15.5 ID%/g), decreased at 60 min (20.5 ± 10.1 ID%/g)
contextSnippet: A biodistribution study in triple mutant mice showed the highest uptake in the pancreas at 5 min post-injection (15.8 ± 1.6 ID%/g). The tracer uptake in the pancreas increased at 30 min (24.4 ± 15.5 ID%/g), followed by a decreased uptake at 60 min (20.5 ± 10.1 ID%/g).

_publicationTitle: PET Imaging of Neurofibromatosis Type 1 with a Fluorine-18 Labeled Tryptophan Radiotracer.
resourceName: Trp53, Nf1, Suz12 triple mutant mice
details: Stable bone uptake during 90 min scans (1.49 ± 0.65 ID%/g at 5 min vs. 1.44 ± 0.45 ID%/g at 90 min), indicating stability towards defluorination
contextSnippet: The bone uptake in the triple mutant group remained stable during the 90 min scans (1.49 ± 0.65 ID%/g at 5 min vs. 1.44 ± 0.45 ID%/g at 90 min), further indicating the stability of L-[18F]FETrp towards in vivo defluorination.

_publicationTitle: PET Imaging of Neurofibromatosis Type 1 with a Fluorine-18 Labeled Tryptophan Radiotracer.
details: Radiosynthesized with decay-corrected radiochemical yields of 15-28%, specific activity 88-122 GBq/µmol, chemical and enantiomeric purities over 90%, synthesis time ~100 min
contextSnippet: L-[18F]FETrp was radiosynthesized using a one-pot, two-step strategy with decay-corrected radiochemical yields of 15–28%. The specific activity was 88–122 GBq/µmol with chemical and enantiomeric purities over 90%. The entire radiolabeling procedure took approximately 100 min.

_publicationTitle: PET Imaging of Neurofibromatosis Type 1 with a Fluorine-18 Labeled Tryptophan Radiotracer.
details: High tumor uptake (SUV 0.64 ± 0.37) with significantly higher tumor-to-brain ratio than FDG (2.0 ± 0.8 vs. 0.7 ± 0.3, p = 0.01)
contextSnippet: Furthermore, the brain had the lowest uptake (SUV 0.31 ± 0.08) and a high tumor uptake (SUV 0.64 ± 0.37)... L-[18F]FETrp showed a significantly higher tumor-to-brain ratio than FDG (2.0 ± 0.8 vs. 0.7 ± 0.3, p = 0.01)

_publicationTitle: PET Imaging of Neurofibromatosis Type 1 with a Fluorine-18 Labeled Tryptophan Radiotracer.
details: Metabolically stable with low brain uptake (0.51 ± 0.10 ID%/g at 5 min vs. 1.17 ± 0.15 ID%/g at 90 min) and stable bone uptake indicating no defluorination
contextSnippet: The bone uptake was stable during the 90-min uptake period (1.91 ± 0.52 ID%/g at 5 min post-injection vs. 1.78 ± 0.24 ID%/g at 90 min), indicating the tracer was metabolically stable towards defluorination.

_publicationTitle: PET Imaging of Neurofibromatosis Type 1 with a Fluorine-18 Labeled Tryptophan Radiotracer.
details: Successfully performed 60-min static scans and dynamic PET imaging in wild-type and NF1 tumor mice, enabling quantitative SUV measurements
contextSnippet: First, we performed 60-min static scans in wild-type mice and NF1 tumor mice with L-[18F]FETrp and compared the imaging results with the most widely used PET radiotracer, FDG.

_publicationTitle: PET Imaging of Neurofibromatosis Type 1 with a Fluorine-18 Labeled Tryptophan Radiotracer.

contextSnippet: The IHC results showed that the NF1 tumors had high IDO, TDO2, and AHR expressions, which is associated with a high tumor uptake of L-[18F]FETrp in PET imaging. However, both brain and muscle showed low IDO and TDO2 expressions

_publicationTitle: PET Imaging of Neurofibromatosis Type 1 with a Fluorine-18 Labeled Tryptophan Radiotracer.

contextSnippet: The IHC results showed that the NF1 tumors had high IDO, TDO2, and AHR expressions, which is associated with a high tumor uptake of L-[18F]FETrp in PET imaging. However, both brain and muscle showed low IDO and TDO2 expressions

_publicationTitle: PET Imaging of Neurofibromatosis Type 1 with a Fluorine-18 Labeled Tryptophan Radiotracer.

contextSnippet: The IHC results showed that the NF1 tumors had high IDO, TDO2, and AHR expressions, which is associated with a high tumor uptake of L-[18F]FETrp in PET imaging... while the AHR expression in the muscle was high.

contextSnippet: Collaborative data platforms (e.g., SYNAPSE, CTF Data Portal) should be leveraged to harmonize datasets and annotation standards.

_publicationTitle: DLK1 Distinguishes Subsets of NF1-Associated Malignant Peripheral Nerve Sheath Tumors with Divergent Molecular Signatures.
details: DLK1+ tumors associated with significantly worse overall survival (347 vs. 1739 days, p=0.0443)
contextSnippet: Correlation of DLK1 staining with clinical data from our institutional cohort (n=15) revealed DLK1+ tumors to be associated with a significantly worse overall survival (347 vs. 1739 days, p=0.0443)

_publicationTitle: DLK1 Distinguishes Subsets of NF1-Associated Malignant Peripheral Nerve Sheath Tumors with Divergent Molecular Signatures.
details: Statistical significance (p=0.0443) for survival difference between DLK1+ and DLK1- MPNST tumors
contextSnippet: revealed DLK1+ tumors to be associated with a significantly worse overall survival (347 vs. 1739 days, p=0.0443)

_publicationTitle: DLK1 Distinguishes Subsets of NF1-Associated Malignant Peripheral Nerve Sheath Tumors with Divergent Molecular Signatures.
details: DLK1 protein expression significantly upregulated in MPNST compared to both PNF and ANNUBP
contextSnippet: we performed immunohistochemical staining of PNST tumors (n=34) obtained from patients (n=22) cared for at our institution. Consistent with our above results, we found DLK1 protein expression to be significantly upregulated in MPNST

_publicationTitle: DLK1 Distinguishes Subsets of NF1-Associated Malignant Peripheral Nerve Sheath Tumors with Divergent Molecular Signatures.
details: Significant decrease in MTAP expression in DLK1 Hi MPNST tumors
contextSnippet: Confirmatory IHC of MPNST from our institutional cohort (n=13) revealed a significant decrease in MTAP expression in DLK1 Hi MPNST

_publicationTitle: DLK1 Distinguishes Subsets of NF1-Associated Malignant Peripheral Nerve Sheath Tumors with Divergent Molecular Signatures.
details: NF1-MPNST from institutional cohort distinguishable by DLK1 expression with enrichment of developmental and differentiation pathways in DLK1 Hi tumors
contextSnippet: we performed bulk RNA sequencing on tumors (n=10) obtained from patients cared for at our institution. Congruent with the above results, NF1-MPNST from our institutional cohort were also distinguishable by DLK1 expression

_publicationTitle: DLK1 Distinguishes Subsets of NF1-Associated Malignant Peripheral Nerve Sheath Tumors with Divergent Molecular Signatures.
details: DLK1 Hi cluster characterized by suppression of immune response genes and upregulation of developmental process genes
contextSnippet: we performed spatial transcriptomic profiling of an MPNST-contiguous ANNUBP, which revealed a region of elevated DLK1 expression. Compared to the surrounding DLK1 Lo tissue, this DLK1 Hi cluster (#5) was characterized by the suppression of genes involved in the immune response

_publicationTitle: DLK1 Distinguishes Subsets of NF1-Associated Malignant Peripheral Nerve Sheath Tumors with Divergent Molecular Signatures.
details: Schwann cells identified as source of DLK1 expression with elevated expression of stem cell markers (POSTN, GAP43, NGFR, PTN, PTPRZ1)
contextSnippet: Surface plots of Schwann cell specific markers S100B, and NES revealed elevated, but not restricted, expression within the DLK1 Hi cluster, implicating Schwann cells as the source of DLK1 expression

_publicationTitle: Analysis of muscle tissue in vivo using fiber-optic autofluorescence and diffuse reflectance spectroscopy.
details: Quadriceps muscle showed significantly different AF spectra means (p < 0.05 between ~450 and 720 nm) and DR spectra with more pronounced absorption feature between 500-600 nm compared to controls
contextSnippet: Normalized AF spectra from B6 and NF1 quadricep muscles showed significantly different means (p < 0.05 between ~450 and 720 nm). NF1 DR spectra showed a more pronounced absorption feature between 500 and 600 nm

_publicationTitle: Analysis of muscle tissue in vivo using fiber-optic autofluorescence and diffuse reflectance spectroscopy.
details: Strong quadriceps separability from controls demonstrated by QDC classifier AUCs of 0.99 for AF and 0.97 for DR spectroscopy
contextSnippet: Both AF and DR demonstrated strong quadriceps separability as indicated by distinct PC score clustering and QDC classifier AUC's of 0.99 and 0.97, respectively

_publicationTitle: Analysis of muscle tissue in vivo using fiber-optic autofluorescence and diffuse reflectance spectroscopy.
details: Quadriceps muscle histology showed endomysial fibrosis and intramyocellular lipid accumulation by H&E and Oil Red O staining
contextSnippet: NF1 muscle histology showed endomysial fibrosis and intramyocellular lipid by H&E and Oil Red O staining, respectively, consistent with prior findings

_publicationTitle: Analysis of muscle tissue in vivo using fiber-optic autofluorescence and diffuse reflectance spectroscopy.
details: Cardiac muscle showed no spectral differences from controls (p > 0.05) with poor QDC classification performance (ROC-AUCs of 0.67 AF, 0.63 DR)
contextSnippet: B6 and NF1 cardiac muscle showed similar spectral shapes and the same mean normalized intensity across almost all wavelengths for both AF and DR (p > 0.05). This similarity resulted in overlapping PC score clusters and poor QDC classification performance with ROC-AUCs of 0.67 and 0.63

_publicationTitle: Analysis of muscle tissue in vivo using fiber-optic autofluorescence and diffuse reflectance spectroscopy.
details: Strong AF separability from controls at 3 weeks (AUC = 0.98) and 10 weeks (AUC = 0.87), with modest DR separability (AUC = 0.73 at 3 weeks, 0.77 at 10 weeks)
contextSnippet: B10WT and B10 mdx mice were compared at 3 weeks, with strong AF separability, AUC = 0.98 and with more modest DR separability, AUC = 0.73. Finally, B10WT and B10 mdx mice were compared at 10 weeks, with similar results to that of 3 weeks, with stronger separability using AF, AUC = 0.87 and modest separability using DR, AUC = 0.77

_publicationTitle: Analysis of muscle tissue in vivo using fiber-optic autofluorescence and diffuse reflectance spectroscopy.
details: 10-week-old quadriceps muscle showed centralized nuclei and degenerating/regenerating muscle fibers by H&E staining, while 3-week-old muscle showed no pathological features
contextSnippet: Histology of B10 mdx mouse quadricep muscle found features of dystrophy consistent with the literature. This included centralized nuclei and degenerating/regenerating muscle fibers as seen using H&E histological staining. 3-week-old B10 mdx mouse muscle showed no pathological features

_publicationTitle: Analysis of muscle tissue in vivo using fiber-optic autofluorescence and diffuse reflectance spectroscopy.
details: Strong temporal separability between 3 and 10 weeks using AF spectroscopy (AUC = 0.96) and modest separability using DR (AUC = 0.77)
contextSnippet: B10 mdx at 3 and 10 weeks showed differences in AF spectral features resulting in strong classifier performance, AUC = 0.96, whereas DR spectra were only modestly separable, AUC = 0.77

_publicationTitle: Analysis of muscle tissue in vivo using fiber-optic autofluorescence and diffuse reflectance spectroscopy.
details: Cardiac muscle was well separable from all skeletal muscles in both AF and DR analyses (AUC = 1 for both), while skeletal muscles were less separable with AUCs ranging between 0.79 and 0.99
contextSnippet: The cardiac muscle was well separable from all skeletal muscles in both AF and DR analyses (AUC = 1 for AF and DR, respectively), whereas skeletal muscles (Quad, Gastr, and TA) were less separable with AUCs ranging between 0.79 and 0.99

_publicationTitle: Analysis of muscle tissue in vivo using fiber-optic autofluorescence and diffuse reflectance spectroscopy.
details: Used for statistical analysis and PCA-based spectral analysis with QDC classification achieving AUCs ranging from 0.58 to 0.99 across different muscle comparisons
contextSnippet: Statistical analysis of normalized spectra was applied to generate 95% confidence intervals. To enhance muscle group separability and resulting classification accuracy, spectra were dimensionally reduced using PCA

_publicationTitle: Neurofibromin-deficient fibroblasts fail to form perineurium in vitro.
details: 80% of Nf1 (-/-) fibroblast cell strains showed increased growth over wild-type cultures in 5-day growth assays
contextSnippet: This result has been replicated in 5-day growth assays of fibroblasts from over 100 Nf1 mouse embryos: 80% of Nf1 (−/−) cell strains showed increased growth over wild-type cultures.

_publicationTitle: Neurofibromin-deficient fibroblasts fail to form perineurium in vitro.
details: Fibroblasts from Nf1 (-/-) embryos contained no detectable neurofibromin by Western blot analysis
contextSnippet: Western blot analysis confirmed that fibroblasts from Nf1 (−/−) embryos contained no detectable neurofibromin, while heterozygous cells showed a reduction as compared to wild-type cells

_publicationTitle: Neurofibromin-deficient fibroblasts fail to form perineurium in vitro.
details: Nf1 (-/-) cultures showed 1% as many perineurium-surrounded fascicles as wild-type sections at 30 days in vitro
contextSnippet: At 30 days in vitro, Nf1 (−/−) cultures showed 1% as many as those from wild-type sections.

_publicationTitle: Neurofibromin-deficient fibroblasts fail to form perineurium in vitro.
details: Cultures containing Nf1 (-/-) fibroblasts showed 17.7% and 23.8% as many fascicles as wild-type after 37 days in vitro
contextSnippet: Cultures containing fibroblasts without neurofibromin showed 17.7% and 23.8% as many fascicles as those with wild-type fascicles.

_publicationTitle: Neurofibromin-deficient fibroblasts fail to form perineurium in vitro.
details: Nf1 (+/-) fibroblasts contained 60% as many fascicles as wild-type cultures at 30 days in vitro
contextSnippet: Cultures with Nf1 (+/−) fibroblasts contained 60% as many fascicles as wild-type cultures.

_publicationTitle: Neurofibromin-deficient fibroblasts fail to form perineurium in vitro.
details: Heterozygous cells showed reduced neurofibromin levels compared to wild-type cells by Western blot analysis
contextSnippet: Western blot analysis confirmed that fibroblasts from Nf1 (−/−) embryos contained no detectable neurofibromin, while heterozygous cells showed a reduction as compared to wild-type cells

_publicationTitle: Neurofibromin-deficient fibroblasts fail to form perineurium in vitro.
details: Lack of neurofibromin did not appear to cause changes in neuronal differentiation in response to nerve growth factor under culture conditions
contextSnippet: Lack of neurofibromin did not by itself appear to cause changes in neuron-Schwann cell adhesion or in neuronal differentiation in response to nerve growth factor under these culture conditions

_publicationTitle: Neurofibromin-deficient fibroblasts fail to form perineurium in vitro.
details: Enabled identification of perineurial cells with caveolae and basal lamina characteristics in both Nf1 (-/-) and wild-type fibroblast cultures
contextSnippet: Cells with these characteristics were identified in cultures containing both Nf1 (−/−) and wild-type fibroblasts, suggesting that even fibroblasts without neurofibromin are capable of responding to cues

_publicationTitle: Genetic modifiers of neurofibromatosis type 1-associated café-au-lait macule count identified using multi-platform analysis.
details: Used as tissue source for expression studies with limited overlap in blood expression profiles compared to other tissues
contextSnippet: We used LCLs as the source of tissue for our expression studies. As a proxy, LCLs are easy to obtain and culture, but there is limited overlap in blood expression profiles and other tissues

_publicationTitle: Genetic modifiers of neurofibromatosis type 1-associated café-au-lait macule count identified using multi-platform analysis.
details: Successfully processed expression data for ~10,000 transcripts expressed in LCLs for linear regression analysis
contextSnippet: simple linear regression between variation in quantitative phenotype severity and the expression level of each transcript (among ∼10,000 transcripts expressed in the LCLs)

_publicationTitle: Genetic modifiers of neurofibromatosis type 1-associated café-au-lait macule count identified using multi-platform analysis.

contextSnippet: SNP rs4660761 was significant by TRAP analysis in an additive model... [TRAP threshold = 0.05] untransformed CALM... Beta -5.221 p-value 0.020

_publicationTitle: Genetic modifiers of neurofibromatosis type 1-associated café-au-lait macule count identified using multi-platform analysis.

_publicationTitle: Genetic modifiers of neurofibromatosis type 1-associated café-au-lait macule count identified using multi-platform analysis.

contextSnippet: SNP rs7161 is reported to locate to an enhancer region with weak H3K4me1 and strong H3K27ac marks in penile foreskin melanocytes using the HaploReg tool

_publicationTitle: Genetic modifiers of neurofibromatosis type 1-associated café-au-lait macule count identified using multi-platform analysis.

_publicationTitle: Neurofibromatosis type 2 tumor suppressor protein is expressed in oligodendrocytes and regulates cell proliferation and process formation.

contextSnippet: Reduction in cell indices over time amounted to about 20% in rat oligodendrocytes (OLN93)...While only 36% of the control-transfected OLN93 cells showed no process, 66% of Merlin overexpressing cells had no projections

_publicationTitle: Neurofibromatosis type 2 tumor suppressor protein is expressed in oligodendrocytes and regulates cell proliferation and process formation.

_publicationTitle: Neurofibromatosis type 2 tumor suppressor protein is expressed in oligodendrocytes and regulates cell proliferation and process formation.

contextSnippet: to 15% in schwannoma cells (RT4)...Only 26% of control RT4 cells showed no projections, but 53% of Merlin overexpressing RT4 cells failed to build processes

_publicationTitle: Neurofibromatosis type 2 tumor suppressor protein is expressed in oligodendrocytes and regulates cell proliferation and process formation.

_publicationTitle: Neurofibromatosis type 2 tumor suppressor protein is expressed in oligodendrocytes and regulates cell proliferation and process formation.
resourceName: XCELLigence Real Time Cell Analysis System
details: Successfully measured impedance changes over 100 hours, detecting 15-30% reduction in cell index slopes in NF2-overexpressing cells across three cell lines
contextSnippet: All three cell types showed a significant reduction in the slope of the cell indices after NF2 overexpression. Reduction in cell indices over time amounted to about 20% in rat oligodendrocytes (OLN93), to 30% in human oligodendroglioma cells (TC620) and to 15% in schwannoma cells (RT4)

_publicationTitle: Neurofibromatosis type 2 tumor suppressor protein is expressed in oligodendrocytes and regulates cell proliferation and process formation.

_publicationTitle: Genomic imbalance of HMMR/RHAMM regulates the sensitivity and response of malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumour cells to aurora kinase inhibition.

contextSnippet: Despite equivalent growth rates and AURKA abundance in 2884 and S462 cells, however, the cellular responses to MLN8237 were significantly different (p=0.02) with S462 being the more sensitive

_publicationTitle: Genomic imbalance of HMMR/RHAMM regulates the sensitivity and response of malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumour cells to aurora kinase inhibition.
details: 2.2-9.2 fold more sensitive to pan-Aurora inhibitors VX680 (IC-50: 42±10 nM) and C1368 (IC-50: 1302±264 nM) compared to 2884 cells
contextSnippet: S462 cells were also 2.2 – 9.2 fold more sensitive to the pan-Aurora inhibitors VX680 (IC-50- 2884, 387 ±47 nM; S462, 42 ±10 nM) and C1368 (IC-50- 2884, 2925 ±135 nM; S462, 1302 ±264 nM)

_publicationTitle: Genomic imbalance of HMMR/RHAMM regulates the sensitivity and response of malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumour cells to aurora kinase inhibition.
details: 5.6±1.2% of S462 cells (168±25 of 3,000 seeded) capable of forming spheroids under stem cell conditions, with secondary passage forming significantly more spheres
contextSnippet: While no spheroids were identified in 2884 cultures, 5.6 ± 1.2% of S462 cells (168 ±25 of 3,000 seeded) are capable of forming spheroids. Secondary passage formed significantly more spheres

_publicationTitle: Genomic imbalance of HMMR/RHAMM regulates the sensitivity and response of malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumour cells to aurora kinase inhibition.
details: VX680 IC-50: 387±47 nM; C1368 IC-50: 2925±135 nM, showing lower sensitivity compared to S462 cells
contextSnippet: S462 cells were also 2.2 – 9.2 fold more sensitive to the pan-Aurora inhibitors VX680 (IC-50- 2884, 387 ±47 nM; S462, 42 ±10 nM) and C1368 (IC-50- 2884, 2925 ±135 nM; S462, 1302 ±264 nM)

_publicationTitle: Genomic imbalance of HMMR/RHAMM regulates the sensitivity and response of malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumour cells to aurora kinase inhibition.
details: No spheroids identified in 2884 cultures under stem cell conditions, unlike S462 cells
contextSnippet: While no spheroids were identified in 2884 cultures, 5.6 ± 1.2% of S462 cells (168 ±25 of 3,000 seeded) are capable of forming spheroids

_publicationTitle: Genomic imbalance of HMMR/RHAMM regulates the sensitivity and response of malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumour cells to aurora kinase inhibition.
details: Required 400-725 fold higher MLN8237 concentrations to inhibit 50% of cellular growth (IC-50), consistent with negligible AURKA expression
contextSnippet: The 2885 cell-line resisted MLN8237 treatment and required 400-725 fold higher concentrations to inhibit 50% of cellular growth (IC-50), which is consistent with the negligible expression of AURKA in this cell-line

_publicationTitle: Genomic imbalance of HMMR/RHAMM regulates the sensitivity and response of malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumour cells to aurora kinase inhibition.
details: MLN8237 treatment at IC-50 concentrations significantly inhibited sphere formation (166 to 29 spheres, p<0.05) and reduced self-renewal capacity in S462 cells
contextSnippet: By Day 6 (passage 0), sphere formation was significantly inhibited in cells treated with MLN8237 in comparison to the vehicle alone treated cells (166 to 29 spheres in the DMSO and MLN8237 treated cells, respectively. p<0.05)

_publicationTitle: Genomic imbalance of HMMR/RHAMM regulates the sensitivity and response of malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumour cells to aurora kinase inhibition.
details: MLN8237 treatment resulted in loss of nestin staining, strong Tuj1 expression, and neuronal morphological changes with neurite-like extensions in sphere-enriched cells
contextSnippet: MLN8237 treatment, in relation to vehicle alone, modified the cellular fate of sphere cells and resulted in the loss of nestin staining, strong expression of the neuronal marker Tuj1, and morphological changes consistent with neurons, such as neurite-like extensions

_publicationTitle: Genomic imbalance of HMMR/RHAMM regulates the sensitivity and response of malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumour cells to aurora kinase inhibition.
details: Stable RHAMM silencing (65% protein reduction) significantly reduced IC-50 for MLN8237 and VX680 by 2-fold in 2884 cells
contextSnippet: achieved stable reduction of approximately 65% of RHAMM protein after drug selection. The IC-50 for MLN8237 and VX680 were significantly reduced in sub-lines in which HMMR/RHAMM was silenced

_publicationTitle: Genomic imbalance of HMMR/RHAMM regulates the sensitivity and response of malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumour cells to aurora kinase inhibition.
details: RHAMM silencing endowed 2884 cells with capacity to both propagate and self-renew as sphere-forming cells
contextSnippet: However, the stable silencing of HMMR/ RHAMM endowed 2884 cells with the capacity to both propagate and self-renew as sphere-forming cells

_publicationTitle: Genomic imbalance of HMMR/RHAMM regulates the sensitivity and response of malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumour cells to aurora kinase inhibition.
details: TPX2 silencing (40% protein reduction) did not alter IC-50 for MLN8237 or VX680 in S462 cells
contextSnippet: reduced TPX2 protein abundance by approximately 40%. However, the reduced expression of TPX2 did not alter the IC-50 for MLN8237 or VX680

_publicationTitle: Genomic imbalance of HMMR/RHAMM regulates the sensitivity and response of malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumour cells to aurora kinase inhibition.
details: TPX2 knockdown significantly reduced sphere self-renewal capacity in passage 1 but not passage 0 formation in S462 cells
contextSnippet: Stable silencing of TPX2 did not significantly alter the propagation of sphere-forming S462 cells in the first passage, but may have impacted their self-renewal capacity, as indicated by a significant reduction in the number of spheres formed during the second passage

_publicationTitle: Genomic imbalance of HMMR/RHAMM regulates the sensitivity and response of malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumour cells to aurora kinase inhibition.
details: Sphere-enriched S462 cells contained higher levels of auto-activated pAURKA (Thr288) indicating increased AURKA activity versus adherent cells
contextSnippet: In comparison to adherent S462 cell lysates, sphere-enriched S462 lysates (sphere) contain higher levels of auto-activated pAURKA (Thr288) indicating increased AURKA activity in sphere versus adherent S462 cells

_publicationTitle: Single-cell multiomics identifies clinically relevant mesenchymal stem-like cells and key regulators for MPNST malignancy.
details: Developed MPNST-like tumors at distinct anatomical locations in dermal, paraspinal, and sciatic nerves
contextSnippet: The genetically engineered mouse models develop MPNST-like tumors (referred as mMPNST) at distinct anatomical locations in dermal, paraspinal, and sciatic nerves

_publicationTitle: Single-cell multiomics identifies clinically relevant mesenchymal stem-like cells and key regulators for MPNST malignancy.
details: Life span of approximately 4 months
contextSnippet: Similar to the mMPNST (Lats1/2-def) model, NPE-mut had a life span of approximately 4 months

_publicationTitle: Single-cell multiomics identifies clinically relevant mesenchymal stem-like cells and key regulators for MPNST malignancy.
details: SC lineage cells enriched with MES-SCP/NC–like cells were highly tumorigenic when engrafted in immunocompromised mice and able to propagate tumors resembling aggressive MPNST when serially transplanted
contextSnippet: SC lineage cells enriched with MES-SCP/NC–like cells isolated from NPE-mut sciatic nerve tumors were highly tumorigenic when engrafted in immunocompromised mice. They were able to propagate tumors that resembled aggressive MPNST when serially transplanted

_publicationTitle: Single-cell multiomics identifies clinically relevant mesenchymal stem-like cells and key regulators for MPNST malignancy.
details: Silencing ZEB1 expression significantly inhibited tumor cell proliferation and induced apoptosis in human MPNST cell lines
contextSnippet: we performed small interfering RNA (siRNA)–mediated knockdown in different human MPNST cell lines and found that silencing the expression of ZEB1 significantly inhibited tumor cell proliferation and induced apoptosis

_publicationTitle: Single-cell multiomics identifies clinically relevant mesenchymal stem-like cells and key regulators for MPNST malignancy.
details: ZEB1 knockdown did not affect proliferation rate of immortalized SCs or benign NF cells, showing specificity to MPNST cells
contextSnippet: ZEB1 knockdown in both immortalized SCs (ipn02.3λ) and PNF cells (ipn95.11bC and ipn95.6) did not affect the proliferation rate of SCs or benign NF cells assessed by 5-bromo-2′-deoxyuridine (BrdU) incorporation assays

_publicationTitle: Single-cell multiomics identifies clinically relevant mesenchymal stem-like cells and key regulators for MPNST malignancy.
details: Lentivirus shRNA-mediated knockdown of ZEB1 impeded tumor growth of MPNST cell line in xenograft assays compared to control shRNA
contextSnippet: by in vivo xenograft assays, we showed that lentivirus short hairpin RNA (shRNA)–mediated knockdown of ZEB1 impeded the tumor growth of an MPNST cell line when compared with control shRNA

_publicationTitle: Single-cell multiomics identifies clinically relevant mesenchymal stem-like cells and key regulators for MPNST malignancy.
details: Knockdown of ALDH1A1 blocked MPNST tumor cell proliferation
contextSnippet: Similarly, knockdown of an EMT/stemness regulator ALDH1A1 also blocked MPNST tumor cell proliferation

_publicationTitle: Single-cell multiomics identifies clinically relevant mesenchymal stem-like cells and key regulators for MPNST malignancy.
details: Used in xenograft assays where ZEB1 shRNA knockdown impeded tumor growth compared to control
contextSnippet: lentivirus short hairpin RNA (shRNA)–mediated knockdown of ZEB1 impeded the tumor growth of an MPNST cell line when compared with control shRNA

_publicationTitle: Single-cell multiomics identifies clinically relevant mesenchymal stem-like cells and key regulators for MPNST malignancy.
details: Successfully performed single-cell transcriptome profiling to characterize cellular diversity along malignant transformation of nerve-associated tumors
contextSnippet: we performed single-cell transcriptome profiling [single-cell RNA sequencing (scRNA-seq)] using the Drop-seq platform

_publicationTitle: Single-cell multiomics identifies clinically relevant mesenchymal stem-like cells and key regulators for MPNST malignancy.
details: Used for species integration platform to visualize human MPNST cells co-embedded with advanced-stage mouse MPNST cells, showing cell types overwhelmingly mapped to corresponding mouse cell phenotypes despite species difference
contextSnippet: Using the Seurat species integration platform, we visualized human MPNST cells co-embedded with advanced-stage mouse MPNST cells. Despite the species difference, cell types in human MPNST overwhelmingly mapped to the corresponding mouse cell phenotypes

_publicationTitle: Single-cell multiomics identifies clinically relevant mesenchymal stem-like cells and key regulators for MPNST malignancy.
details: Successfully used to infer putative cellular identities of SC-derived tumor phenotypes using reference profiles of developing neural lineages and neural crest cell types from human embryos
contextSnippet: To infer the putative cellular identities of SC-derived tumor phenotypes, we used reference profiles of the developing neural lineages and neural crest cell types from human embryos by CIBERSORTx

_publicationTitle: Single-cell multiomics identifies clinically relevant mesenchymal stem-like cells and key regulators for MPNST malignancy.
details: Identified advanced tumor-specific mesenchymal neural crest–like tumor cells as the stem cell–like starting cell population following a differentiation path toward more committed SC lineage populations
contextSnippet: we identified advanced tumor-specific mesenchymal neural crest–like tumor cells as the stem cell–like starting cell population; these cells followed a differentiation path toward tumor neural crest–like cells, mesenchymal SCPs, and subsequently to more committed SC lineage populations

_publicationTitle: Single-cell multiomics identifies clinically relevant mesenchymal stem-like cells and key regulators for MPNST malignancy.
details: Determined tumorigenesis trajectory initiated in mature SCs, proceeded through neoplastic SC subpopulation, reached bifurcation point with mesenchymal traits, and ended in MES-NC–like tumor subclusters
contextSnippet: The tumorigenesis trajectory initiated in mature SCs, proceeded through a neoplastic SC subpopulation, reached a bifurcation point enriched with tumor-like SCPs with mesenchymal traits, and ended in the MES-NC–like tumor subclusters

_publicationTitle: Single-cell multiomics identifies clinically relevant mesenchymal stem-like cells and key regulators for MPNST malignancy.
details: Predicted most differentiated cell cluster as myelinating SC cluster and most stem cell–like population as tumor cell cluster with neural crest/mesenchymal phenotype, consistent with dedifferentiation path
contextSnippet: Consistent with a dedifferentiation path, the most differentiated cell cluster is the myelinating SC cluster, whereas the most stem cell–like population is the tumor cell cluster with neural crest/mesenchymal phenotype

_publicationTitle: Susceptible stages in Schwann cells for NF1-associated plexiform neurofibroma development.
details: Efficiently induced recombination in neonate sciatic nerves, dorsal root ganglia (DRG) and trigeminal ganglia when tamoxifen administered to lactating mothers for first five days after birth
contextSnippet: Oral tamoxifen administration to mothers for the first five days after birth, efficiently induced recombination in neonate sciatic nerves, dorsal root ganglia (DRG) and trigeminal ganglia as assessed by X-gal staining

_publicationTitle: Susceptible stages in Schwann cells for NF1-associated plexiform neurofibroma development.
details: Tamoxifen administration to adult (2-3 months old) mice induced recombination in sciatic nerves, DRG, and trigeminal ganglia
contextSnippet: tamoxifen administration to adult (2- to 3-months old) mice induced recombination in sciatic nerves, DRG, and trigeminal ganglia thus demonstrating the power and specificity of the temporally- and spatially-inducible PLPCre-ERT2 transgene

_publicationTitle: Susceptible stages in Schwann cells for NF1-associated plexiform neurofibroma development.
details: 100% of E12.5 tamoxifen-induced PLPCre-ERT2;NF1 flox/− mice developed plexiform neurofibromas at 5-6 months of age
contextSnippet: The E12.5 PLPCre-ERT2;NF1 flox/− ;R26R progeny showed classic signs of illness beginning at 5 to 6-months of age and were necropsied along with control littermates. In all cases, the mice exhibited tumors along the cervical and thoracic DRG

_publicationTitle: Susceptible stages in Schwann cells for NF1-associated plexiform neurofibroma development.
details: 100% of P0 tamoxifen-induced PLPCre-ERT2;NF1 flox/− mice developed plexiform neurofibromas at 5-6 months of age
contextSnippet: the P0 tam;PLPCre-ERT2;NF1 flox/− mice began to show signs of lethargy, weight loss and paralysis at five to six-months of age requiring that they be sacrificed

_publicationTitle: Susceptible stages in Schwann cells for NF1-associated plexiform neurofibroma development.
details: Only 2 out of 19 (10.5%) adult tamoxifen-induced PLPCre-ERT2;NF1 flox/− mice developed plexiform neurofibromas in their second year of life
contextSnippet: Two out of nineteen Atam;PLPCre-ERT2;NF1 flox/− ;R26R mice were sacrificed in their second year of life when they developed signs of sickness including lethargy, ruffled hair, weight loss, and limb paralysis

_publicationTitle: Susceptible stages in Schwann cells for NF1-associated plexiform neurofibroma development.
details: All E12.5 PLPCre-ERT2;NF1 flox/− tumors exhibited Schwann cell marker (S100β) immunoreactivity
contextSnippet: Tumor sections were also evaluated immunohistochemically and all the E12.5 PLPCre-ERT2;NF1 flox/− ;R26R tumors exhibited Schwann cell marker (S100β) immunoreactivity

_publicationTitle: Susceptible stages in Schwann cells for NF1-associated plexiform neurofibroma development.
details: P0 tamoxifen-induced neurofibromas expressed Schwann cell marker S100β
contextSnippet: These neurofibromas exhibited the classic characteristics of human plexiform neurofibromas, being poorly circumscribed, composed primarily of spindle cells, and expressing the Schwann cell markers S100β and GAP43

_publicationTitle: Susceptible stages in Schwann cells for NF1-associated plexiform neurofibroma development.
details: P0 tamoxifen-induced neurofibromas expressed Schwann cell marker GAP43
contextSnippet: These neurofibromas exhibited the classic characteristics of human plexiform neurofibromas, being poorly circumscribed, composed primarily of spindle cells, and expressing the Schwann cell markers S100β and GAP43

_publicationTitle: Susceptible stages in Schwann cells for NF1-associated plexiform neurofibroma development.
details: Enabled verification of Cre-mediated recombination through X-gal staining in peripheral nerve plexuses at E12.5
contextSnippet: we verified the capability of PLPCre-ERT2 to ablate genes of interest in peripheral nerves by crossing into the Flox-stop-Flox ROSA26 (R26R) reporter background to generate PLPCre-ERT2;R26R mice

_publicationTitle: Global proteomics and affinity mass spectrometry analysis of human Schwann cells indicates that variation in and loss of neurofibromin (NF1) alters protein expression and cellular and mitochondrial metabolism.

contextSnippet: NADH-linked OXPHOS and electron transfer capacity was ~ 1.5fold lower in NF1 -/- cells compared to NF1 +/+ (Fig. 5 C-E)

_publicationTitle: Global proteomics and affinity mass spectrometry analysis of human Schwann cells indicates that variation in and loss of neurofibromin (NF1) alters protein expression and cellular and mitochondrial metabolism.
details: NF1 knockout cells displayed ~30% reduction in OXPHOS and electron transfer capacity with convergent substrate flow
contextSnippet: NF1 -/- cells displayed a ~ 30% reduction in OXPHOS and electron transfer capacity associated with convergent flow of NADH-linked substrates and succinate

_publicationTitle: Global proteomics and affinity mass spectrometry analysis of human Schwann cells indicates that variation in and loss of neurofibromin (NF1) alters protein expression and cellular and mitochondrial metabolism.
details: 148 proteins significantly altered in NF1 knockout vs wild-type cells (68 increased, 76 decreased)
contextSnippet: We identified 148 proteins that were significantly altered in spectral count abundance in the WT and null ipn97.4 cells; 68 proteins are increased and 76 proteins are decreased

_publicationTitle: Global proteomics and affinity mass spectrometry analysis of human Schwann cells indicates that variation in and loss of neurofibromin (NF1) alters protein expression and cellular and mitochondrial metabolism.
details: Successfully inactivated both NF1 alleles in ipn97.4 cells with no detected off-target effects by whole genome sequencing
contextSnippet: We used CRISPR Cas9 to inactivate both NF1 alleles in parental human immortalized human Schwann cell line ipn97.4 cells...To ensure no off-target CRISPR effects we utilized whole genome sequencing

_publicationTitle: Global proteomics and affinity mass spectrometry analysis of human Schwann cells indicates that variation in and loss of neurofibromin (NF1) alters protein expression and cellular and mitochondrial metabolism.
