contextSnippet: We purified 104 unique proteins in ipn97.4 NF1 -/- cells stably expressing the WT m Nf1 cDNA...We identified 98 protein interactions that have no non-specific binding

_publicationTitle: Global proteomics and affinity mass spectrometry analysis of human Schwann cells indicates that variation in and loss of neurofibromin (NF1) alters protein expression and cellular and mitochondrial metabolism.
details: Variant forms showed 31-67 proteins specific to wild-type compared to each of four variants tested
contextSnippet: Of the 104 PPI's seen for the WT cDNA expressing ipn97.4 NF1 -/- cells, 31–67 proteins are seen to be specific to the WT compared to each of the four variants

_publicationTitle: Global proteomics and affinity mass spectrometry analysis of human Schwann cells indicates that variation in and loss of neurofibromin (NF1) alters protein expression and cellular and mitochondrial metabolism.
details: Successfully affinity purified NF1 protein-protein interactions using streptavidin tag system
contextSnippet: The streptavidin tag was used to affinity purify PPIs using StrepTactin beads. Non-specific binders were removed by identifying proteins that were affinity purified with beads

_publicationTitle: Global proteomics and affinity mass spectrometry analysis of human Schwann cells indicates that variation in and loss of neurofibromin (NF1) alters protein expression and cellular and mitochondrial metabolism.
resourceName: Thermo Q Exactive HFx mass spectrometer
details: Identified 1,933 proteins in wild-type cells and 1,952 proteins in NF1 knockout cells
contextSnippet: We observed a total of 1,933 proteins in the WT (+/+) ipn97.4 cells, and 1,952 total proteins in the NF1 null (-/-) ipn97.4 cells

_publicationTitle: Global proteomics and affinity mass spectrometry analysis of human Schwann cells indicates that variation in and loss of neurofibromin (NF1) alters protein expression and cellular and mitochondrial metabolism.
details: Predicted decreased oxidative phosphorylation and myelination signaling, increased mitochondrial dysfunction and glycolysis upon NF1 loss
contextSnippet: upon loss of NF1 there is a decrease in oxidative phosphorylation (OXPHOS) and Myelination Signaling Pathway. We see increases in Mitochondrial dysfunction and Glycolysis

_publicationTitle: Global proteomics and affinity mass spectrometry analysis of human Schwann cells indicates that variation in and loss of neurofibromin (NF1) alters protein expression and cellular and mitochondrial metabolism.
details: Measured mitochondrial respiratory function showing NF1 stabilizes NADH-linked OXPHOS and electron transfer capacity
contextSnippet: NF1 impacts mitochondrial respiratory function by stabilizing NADH-linked OXPHOS and electron transfer capacity in Schwann cells

_publicationTitle: Combining nonsense mutation suppression therapy with nonsense-mediated decay inhibition in neurofibromatosis type 1.
details: 100% of animals displayed café au lait macules (CALMs) and a subset developed lesions resembling NF1-associated cutaneous neurofibromas
contextSnippet: The phenotype of these NF1 minipigs was very similar to what was previously reported, with 100% of the animals displaying café au lait macules (CALMs) and a subset of NF1 minipigs developed lesions resembling NF1-associated cutaneous neurofibromas

_publicationTitle: Combining nonsense mutation suppression therapy with nonsense-mediated decay inhibition in neurofibromatosis type 1.
details: NF1 minipigs were viable, fertile, and transmitted the mutant allele to future generations with Mendelian frequencies
contextSnippet: NF1 minipigs were viable, fertile, and transmitted the mutant allele to future generations with Mendelian frequencies

_publicationTitle: Combining nonsense mutation suppression therapy with nonsense-mediated decay inhibition in neurofibromatosis type 1.
details: Schwann cells were purified to >95% purity by flow cytometry using p75 NGFR antibody-mediated magnetic cell separation
contextSnippet: Schwann cells were purified from contaminating cells using p75 nerve growth factor receptor (NGFR) antibody-mediated magnetic cell separation and confirmed to be >95% pure by flow cytometry

_publicationTitle: Combining nonsense mutation suppression therapy with nonsense-mediated decay inhibition in neurofibromatosis type 1.
details: Gentamicin was well tolerated with no significant changes in renal parameters, including serum creatinine and blood urea nitrogen
contextSnippet: Gentamicin was well tolerated with no significant changes in renal parameters, including serum creatinine and blood urea nitrogen

_publicationTitle: Combining nonsense mutation suppression therapy with nonsense-mediated decay inhibition in neurofibromatosis type 1.
details: Mean Cmax of 38 μg/mL on day 1, with no significant changes in PK parameters after 14 days
contextSnippet: PK parameters reached a mean Cmax of 38 μg/mL on day 1, and no significant changes in PK parameters were noted after 14 days, suggesting that gentamicin did not accumulate in the plasma over time

_publicationTitle: Combining nonsense mutation suppression therapy with nonsense-mediated decay inhibition in neurofibromatosis type 1.
details: Tissue concentrations: 5.87 ± 0.97 μg/mL in optic nerve, 1.01 ± 0.2 μg/mL in cortex, 6.88 ± 1.54 μg/mL in sciatic nerve, and 3.02 ± 1.28 μg/mL in skin
contextSnippet: Gentamicin was present in all tissues and reached a mean concentration of 5.87 ± 0.97 μg/mL in optic nerve, 1.01 ± 0.2 μg/mL in cortex, 6.88 ± 1.54 μg/mL in sciatic nerve, and 3.02 ± 1.28 μg/mL in skin

_publicationTitle: Combining nonsense mutation suppression therapy with nonsense-mediated decay inhibition in neurofibromatosis type 1.
details: Significantly increased neurofibromin protein expression in optic nerve tissue (p = 0.01) but no significant change in other tissues
contextSnippet: Neurofibromin protein expression was higher in the optic nerve tissue of animals treated with gentamicin compared with untreated controls (p = 0.01), but no significant change was observed in other tissues

_publicationTitle: Combining nonsense mutation suppression therapy with nonsense-mediated decay inhibition in neurofibromatosis type 1.
details: Caused significant and dose-dependent increase in firefly luciferase activity in dual luciferase reporter assay in both minipig and human Schwann cells
contextSnippet: Treatment with G418, but not gentamicin or ataluren, caused a significant and dose-dependent increase in firefly luciferase activity compared with vehicle-treated cells in both minipig and human Schwann cells

_publicationTitle: Combining nonsense mutation suppression therapy with nonsense-mediated decay inhibition in neurofibromatosis type 1.
details: In combination with siUPF1, restored detectable full-length neurofibromin protein expression in NF1 Schwann cells
contextSnippet: However, treatment with siUPF1 in combination with G418 restored detectable full-length neurofibromin protein expression in NF1 Schwann cells

_publicationTitle: Combining nonsense mutation suppression therapy with nonsense-mediated decay inhibition in neurofibromatosis type 1.
details: Did not cause significant increase in firefly luciferase activity in dual luciferase reporter assay
contextSnippet: Treatment with G418, but not gentamicin or ataluren, caused a significant and dose-dependent increase in firefly luciferase activity

_publicationTitle: Combining nonsense mutation suppression therapy with nonsense-mediated decay inhibition in neurofibromatosis type 1.

contextSnippet: NF1 Schwann cells were treated with siRNA targeting swine UPF1, which resulted in a 50% reduction in UPF1 transcript corresponding to a 75% reduction in UPF1 protein expression and a 2- to 3-fold increase in NF1 mRNA expression

_publicationTitle: Combining nonsense mutation suppression therapy with nonsense-mediated decay inhibition in neurofibromatosis type 1.

contextSnippet: Transcript levels of NF1 were decreased by roughly 50% in NF1 Schwann cells from NF1 minipig sciatic nerve compared with WT, and by 90% in NF1 and NF1 Schwann cells

_publicationTitle: Combining nonsense mutation suppression therapy with nonsense-mediated decay inhibition in neurofibromatosis type 1.

contextSnippet: Schwann cells derived from cutaneous neurofibromas showed altered morphology, disorganized architecture, and increased proliferation compared with WT and NF1 sciatic nerve-derived Schwann cells

_publicationTitle: Combining nonsense mutation suppression therapy with nonsense-mediated decay inhibition in neurofibromatosis type 1.

contextSnippet: Proliferation assay showing increased proliferation in NF1 Schwann cells compared with WT and NF1 Schwann cells

contextSnippet: At 5–7 DIV, the Ca2+ current density was ~75% higher in neurons from Nf1+/− wild-type mice: 37.7 ± 4.2 (n=9) versus versus 21.5 ± 3.7 (n=10) pA pF−1 (Vt=0 mV, p <0.05, Student's t-test).

_publicationTitle: ALTERED CALCIUM CURRENTS AND AXONAL GROWTH IN Nf1 HAPLOINSUFFICIENT MICE.

contextSnippet: Alignment of the S. scrofa canonical AHR CDS (ENSSSCT00000031031.4) to the WMS TM genome produced a CDS encoding an 844-long AHR amino acid that shared a 98.35% identity match to the S. scrofa AHR amino acid sequence... the WMS TM AHR amino acid sequence shared an 81.66% identity match to the human AHR (699/856 positions)

_publicationTitle: The draft genome of the Wisconsin Miniature SwineTM, a valuable biomedical research tool.

contextSnippet: Ordination analysis of biallelic SNPs revealed robust segregation of unique subpopulations, with the first 3 principal components explaining 65% of the variance in the dataset. Notably, a single principal component clearly distinguished between WMS TM -WT and WMS TM -FH samples

_publicationTitle: The draft genome of the Wisconsin Miniature SwineTM, a valuable biomedical research tool.

_publicationTitle: The draft genome of the Wisconsin Miniature SwineTM, a valuable biomedical research tool.

_publicationTitle: The draft genome of the Wisconsin Miniature SwineTM, a valuable biomedical research tool.

contextSnippet: The WMS TM draft assembly achieved a BUSCO score of 98.2% ([S:97.9%, D:0.3%], F:1.0%, M:0.8%), indicating that we have a highly complete assembly... The BUSCO assessment of the assembly generated here surpasses the BUSCO scores for existing S. scrofa reference genomes (Sscrofa11.1 = 93.8% and USMARCv1.0 = 93.1%)

_publicationTitle: The draft genome of the Wisconsin Miniature SwineTM, a valuable biomedical research tool.

contextSnippet: When applied to WMS TM , the lift-over annotation resulted in a 97.76% match with Sscrofa11.1 annotations with an alignment coverage and sequence identity ≥50%. The gene features in the S. scrofa genome used in our analysis included 20,306 annotations, of which we identified 19,853 matches (96.4%).

_publicationTitle: Exome sequencing on malignant meningiomas identified mutations in neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF2) and meningioma 1 (MN1) genes.

contextSnippet: After removing low-quality reads, we obtained on average 45 million paired-end 90 bp reads per sample. Alignment statistics showed mean depth coverage of 54X, and 93.4% of bases were covered by at least 10X.

_publicationTitle: Exome sequencing on malignant meningiomas identified mutations in neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF2) and meningioma 1 (MN1) genes.

_publicationTitle: Exome sequencing on malignant meningiomas identified mutations in neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF2) and meningioma 1 (MN1) genes.
details: Achieved higher depth coverage with on average 455X read depth and 100% of targeted regions covered
contextSnippet: Since the targeted region sequencing captures a smaller region compared to WGS or WES, we were able to obtain sequencing data with higher depth coverage on the targeted regions: on average, the read depth is 455X and 100% of targeted regions are covered.

_publicationTitle: Exome sequencing on malignant meningiomas identified mutations in neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF2) and meningioma 1 (MN1) genes.

_publicationTitle: CXCL12 alone is insufficient for gliomagenesis in Nf1 mutant mice.

details: Successfully identified myeloid cells in immunofluorescence staining of cutaneous neurofibromas, showing no significant difference in myeloid cell proportion after selumetinib treatment
contextSnippet: three sets of tumors were used for immunofluorescence staining to evaluate the frequency of Schwann cells and Myeloid cells in the microenvironment between control and treated samples using cell type- specific markers (SOX10 for Schwann cells (green) and CD11b for myeloid cells (red))

_publicationTitle: snRNA-seq of human cutaneous neurofibromas before and after selumetinib treatment implicates role of altered Schwann cell states, inter-cellular signaling, and extracellular matrix in treatment response.
details: Successfully identified Schwann cells in immunofluorescence staining of cutaneous neurofibromas, showing no significant difference in Schwann cell proportion after selumetinib treatment
contextSnippet: three sets of tumors were used for immunofluorescence staining to evaluate the frequency of Schwann cells and Myeloid cells in the microenvironment between control and treated samples using cell type- specific markers (SOX10 for Schwann cells (green) and CD11b for myeloid cells (red))

_publicationTitle: snRNA-seq of human cutaneous neurofibromas before and after selumetinib treatment implicates role of altered Schwann cell states, inter-cellular signaling, and extracellular matrix in treatment response.
details: Successfully processed snRNA-seq data from 11,545 nuclei, yielding 5,844 nuclei from untreated tumors and 5,701 nuclei from 4 matched-paired treated tumors
contextSnippet: A total of 11,545 nuclei were used for analysis in Seurat. Using both mitochondrial content and number of features to filter out low quality nuclei or doublets we obtained 5,844 total nuclei and 30,442 genes from untreated tumors, and 5,701 nuclei and 30,127 genes

_publicationTitle: snRNA-seq of human cutaneous neurofibromas before and after selumetinib treatment implicates role of altered Schwann cell states, inter-cellular signaling, and extracellular matrix in treatment response.
details: Successfully identified 8 distinct cell types including Schwann cells, fibroblasts, myeloid cells, two endothelial populations, pericytes, keratinocytes, and melanocytes from snRNA-seq data
contextSnippet: Using canonical genes from PanglaoDB and literature for specific cell types, we identified cells as: Schwann cells, fibroblasts, myeloid cells, two distinct populations of endothelial cells (endothelial 1 and 2), pericytes, keratinocytes, and a population of melanocytes

_publicationTitle: snRNA-seq of human cutaneous neurofibromas before and after selumetinib treatment implicates role of altered Schwann cell states, inter-cellular signaling, and extracellular matrix in treatment response.
details: Identified significant deactivation of calcium signaling (Z-score -2.309) and opioid signaling pathway (Z-score -1.789) in Schwann cells after selumetinib treatment
contextSnippet: In Schwann cells, we observed a significant deactivation of 'Calcium Signaling' (Z score − 2.309) and deactivation of 'Opioid Signaling Pathway' (Z-score = − 1.789)

_publicationTitle: snRNA-seq of human cutaneous neurofibromas before and after selumetinib treatment implicates role of altered Schwann cell states, inter-cellular signaling, and extracellular matrix in treatment response.
details: Revealed that FN1 signaling from endothelial cells was dramatically inhibited in selumetinib-treated cells, and identified loss of PARS and SELE signaling pathways in treated samples
contextSnippet: FN1 signaling initiates from endothelial cells in untreated samples (brown pathways in Fig. 5 C) but was dramatically inhibited in treated cells... PARS (protease activated receptors) signaling was present in untreated samples, but not detected in treated samples

_publicationTitle: snRNA-seq of human cutaneous neurofibromas before and after selumetinib treatment implicates role of altered Schwann cell states, inter-cellular signaling, and extracellular matrix in treatment response.
details: Demonstrated that selumetinib treatment increased velocity of Schwann cell transformation and altered cell states from 2 main states in untreated to 4 defined states in treated conditions
contextSnippet: For the treated conditions we observed increased velocity of cell transformation, as well as four defined Schwann cell states... For untreated Schwann cells, we observe two main cell states, with a short one-way transition between them

_publicationTitle: snRNA-seq of human cutaneous neurofibromas before and after selumetinib treatment implicates role of altered Schwann cell states, inter-cellular signaling, and extracellular matrix in treatment response.
details: Showed that selumetinib induced a major shift in ligand-receptor profiles of Schwann cells, with loss of most interactions with Endothelial 1 cells except NCAM1-FGFR1
contextSnippet: selumetinib induced a major shift in the ligands-receptors profile of Schwann cells that distinguished them from other populations... Upon treatment the Schwann cells lose most of the ligand-receptor pathways that interact with Endothelial 1 cells and retain only NCAM1-FGFR1

_publicationTitle: Detection of malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumors in patients with neurofibromatosis using aneuploidy and mutation identification in plasma.
details: Amplifies approximately 750,000 loci across 39 chromosome arms to calculate genome wide aneuploidy score (GAS)
contextSnippet: RealSeqS, which amplifies approximately 750,000 loci across 39 chromosome arms, was used to calculate a genome wide aneuploidy score (GAS)

_publicationTitle: Detection of malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumors in patients with neurofibromatosis using aneuploidy and mutation identification in plasma.
details: Achieved 33% sensitivity for detecting MPNST at 97% specificity
contextSnippet: the sensitivity for detecting MPNST was 33% (4/12, p < 0.001 compared to healthy controls)

_publicationTitle: Detection of malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumors in patients with neurofibromatosis using aneuploidy and mutation identification in plasma.
details: False positive rate among benign/plexiform neurofibromas was 6.3% (1/16)

_publicationTitle: Detection of malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumors in patients with neurofibromatosis using aneuploidy and mutation identification in plasma.

_publicationTitle: Detection of malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumors in patients with neurofibromatosis using aneuploidy and mutation identification in plasma.

contextSnippet: the combination of GAS and detection of sub-chromosomal changes in genes such as TERT, TP53, and SUZ12 or mutations in ctDNA may lead to a sensitivity of ~50% at a high specificity of 97%

_publicationTitle: Detection of malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumors in patients with neurofibromatosis using aneuploidy and mutation identification in plasma.
details: Requires relatively low sequencing coverage of ~10 M reads per sample to identify relevant CNAs

_publicationTitle: Detection of malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumors in patients with neurofibromatosis using aneuploidy and mutation identification in plasma.

details: Expressed HER1 antigen, confirmed by flow cytometry analysis

_publicationTitle: Development of CAR-T cell therapy for NF1/SWN-related nerve sheath tumor treatment.
details: Released nearly 2000 pg/ml of TGFβ1 in culture medium
contextSnippet: The concentration of TGFβ1 in the sNF96.2 culture medium reached nearly 2000 pg/ml (Fig. 3 C).

_publicationTitle: Development of CAR-T cell therapy for NF1/SWN-related nerve sheath tumor treatment.
details: Approximately 95% of cells were PDL1-positive
contextSnippet: Additionally, approximately 95% of sNF96.2, T20210108 and T20210618, around 85% of T20210304, T20210401 and T20211105 cells, and nearly 60% of T20210106 cells were PDL1-positive

_publicationTitle: Development of CAR-T cell therapy for NF1/SWN-related nerve sheath tumor treatment.
details: Completely eliminated sNF96.2-luci cells at E:T ratio of 1:1, and lysed 75% of tumor cells at E:T ratio of 0.25:1
contextSnippet: sNF96.2-luci was completely eliminated by all three types of CAR-T cells at an effector to target (E:T) ratio of 1: 1. Notably, 806 exhibited superior performance even at lower E:T ratios. At an E:T ratio of 0.25: 1, E2 and NEC lost their tumor-lysing activity, whereas 806 was still able to lyse 75% of the tumor cells

_publicationTitle: Development of CAR-T cell therapy for NF1/SWN-related nerve sheath tumor treatment.
details: Completely eliminated sNF96.2-luci cells at E:T ratio of 1:1, but lost tumor-lysing activity at E:T ratio of 0.25:1
contextSnippet: sNF96.2-luci was completely eliminated by all three types of CAR-T cells at an effector to target (E:T) ratio of 1: 1. At an E:T ratio of 0.25: 1, E2 and NEC lost their tumor-lysing activity

_publicationTitle: Development of CAR-T cell therapy for NF1/SWN-related nerve sheath tumor treatment.
details: Completely eliminated sNF96.2-luci cells at E:T ratio of 1:1, but lost tumor-lysing activity at E:T ratio of 0.25:1
contextSnippet: sNF96.2-luci was completely eliminated by all three types of CAR-T cells at an effector to target (E:T) ratio of 1: 1. At an E:T ratio of 0.25: 1, E2 and NEC lost their tumor-lysing activity

_publicationTitle: Development of CAR-T cell therapy for NF1/SWN-related nerve sheath tumor treatment.
details: Demonstrated superior efficacy against primary tumor cells at E:T ratio of 0.5:1 compared to E2 and NEC
contextSnippet: Our results showed that three types of CAR-T cells induced varying degree of tumor clearance at an E:T ratio of 0.5:1, with 806 demonstrating superior efficacy

_publicationTitle: Development of CAR-T cell therapy for NF1/SWN-related nerve sheath tumor treatment.
details: Did not exhibit any cytolytic effect on HFFs normal cells despite their HER1 positivity
contextSnippet: Although HFFs are HER1-positive, 806 did not exhibit any cytolytic effect on these normal cells.

contextSnippet: NCI-H266 was completely eliminated at an E:T of 0.2:1, with the lysis decreasing as the E:T ratio was reduced.

_publicationTitle: Development of CAR-T cell therapy for NF1/SWN-related nerve sheath tumor treatment.
details: Did not lyse K562 cells which had no HER1 expression, demonstrating specificity
contextSnippet: As expected, K562 cells were not lysed by 806.

_publicationTitle: Development of CAR-T cell therapy for NF1/SWN-related nerve sheath tumor treatment.

contextSnippet: This advantage became more pronounced at lower E:T ratios of 0.125:1 (806-TKO vs. 806-EP: 76% vs.45%) and 0.0625:1 (806-TKO vs. 806-EP: 24.5% vs. 2.7%).

_publicationTitle: Development of CAR-T cell therapy for NF1/SWN-related nerve sheath tumor treatment.
details: Showed 98.6% HER1 positivity with low expression intensity
contextSnippet: While HFFs showed 98.6% HER1 positivity with low expression intensity.

_publicationTitle: Development of CAR-T cell therapy for NF1/SWN-related nerve sheath tumor treatment.

contextSnippet: NCI-H266 was nearly 100% HER1 positive with high expression intensity.

details: Had no HER1 expression
contextSnippet: K562 had no HER1 expression.

_publicationTitle: Development of CAR-T cell therapy for NF1/SWN-related nerve sheath tumor treatment.

contextSnippet: Interestingly, tumor cells in spheroids were more sensitive to 806 CAR-T cells than those cultured in 2D. As shown in Figure S4E, 806-EP along with other groups achieved complete tumor elimination at a E:T ratio of 0.25:1.

_publicationTitle: Development of CAR-T cell therapy for NF1/SWN-related nerve sheath tumor treatment.
details: Showed substantial infiltration of CD3-positive T cells in spheroids treated with 806 CAR-T cells
contextSnippet: Notably, substantial infiltration of CD3-positive T cells was observed in the spheroids treated with 806 CAR-T cells.

_publicationTitle: Development of CAR-T cell therapy for NF1/SWN-related nerve sheath tumor treatment.

contextSnippet: The spheroids displayed a compact morphology, high expression of HER1 and TGFβ1, and relatively low expression of PDL1, with nearly absent S100 expression

contextSnippet: The lesional skin of the neurofibromas contained S100 + cells (Fig. 7, 16 1 b, j, stained brown)

_publicationTitle: Focused ultrasound-mediated drug delivery of bevacizumab in treating NF2-related schwannomatosis in an animal model.
details: Consistently developed DRG schwannomas detectable by MRI at 2 months, but no vestibular schwannomas up to 13 months of age
contextSnippet: Schwannomas of the DRGs were readily detectable on initial MRI at 2 months...we could not detect vestibular schwannomas on the vestibulocochlear nerve up to 13 months

_publicationTitle: Focused ultrasound-mediated drug delivery of bevacizumab in treating NF2-related schwannomatosis in an animal model.

contextSnippet: pooled lumbar DRG voxel counts across the cohort...age 4–5 months: n = 120, 87.2 ± 30.1; age 7–8 months: n = 68, 109.4 ± 35.5; age 9–11 months: n = 60, 112.4 ± 40.6

_publicationTitle: Focused ultrasound-mediated drug delivery of bevacizumab in treating NF2-related schwannomatosis in an animal model.

contextSnippet: human bevacizumab concentrations were 3.8-fold higher in FUS-treated DRGs (n = 9 tumors; 51.84 ± 41.37 ng/mg tissue) compared to non-FUS-treated DRGs...p = 0.025

_publicationTitle: Focused ultrasound-mediated drug delivery of bevacizumab in treating NF2-related schwannomatosis in an animal model.

contextSnippet: DRGs treated with human bevacizumab + FUS...98.2 ± 43.7; diameter: 0.86 ± 0.14 mm) showed a trend to being smaller (p = 0.035) than those receiving human bevacizumab alone

_publicationTitle: Focused ultrasound-mediated drug delivery of bevacizumab in treating NF2-related schwannomatosis in an animal model.

_publicationTitle: Focused ultrasound-mediated drug delivery of bevacizumab in treating NF2-related schwannomatosis in an animal model.

_publicationTitle: Focused ultrasound-mediated drug delivery of bevacizumab in treating NF2-related schwannomatosis in an animal model.

contextSnippet: repeated general anesthesia procedures contributed to a significant reduction in colony size...animals had to be under anesthesia up to 120 min, which further altered colony survival due to possible hypothermia

_publicationTitle: Focused ultrasound-mediated drug delivery of bevacizumab in treating NF2-related schwannomatosis in an animal model.

contextSnippet: Tumor growth of DRG schwannomas was monitored by MRI...confirmed by pooled lumbar DRG voxel counts...p = 0.021, p = 0.002

_publicationTitle: Focused ultrasound-mediated drug delivery of bevacizumab in treating NF2-related schwannomatosis in an animal model.

contextSnippet: Representative MRI images with gadolinium contrast...Schwannomas of the DRGs were readily detectable on initial MRI at 2 months

_publicationTitle: Pharmacogenomic Synthetic Lethal Screens Reveal Hidden Vulnerabilities and New Therapeutic Approaches for Treatment of NF1-Associated Tumors.
details: NF1-deficient iHSCs showed increased basal RAS-GTP levels compared to NF1-proficient sister clones
contextSnippet: NF1-deficient clones also show increased basal RAS–GTP levels, as expected, when compared with the isogenic-matched NF1-proficient sister clones

_publicationTitle: Pharmacogenomic Synthetic Lethal Screens Reveal Hidden Vulnerabilities and New Therapeutic Approaches for Treatment of NF1-Associated Tumors.
details: NF1-deficient iHSCs exhibited robust colony formation in low-serum soft agar conditions, while NF1-proficient cells formed limited numbers of colonies
contextSnippet: All NF1-deficient lines tested exhibited robust colony formation in these conditions, similar to the phenotype of an HSC1λ cell line in which the tumor-suppressor PTEN has been knocked out

_publicationTitle: Pharmacogenomic Synthetic Lethal Screens Reveal Hidden Vulnerabilities and New Therapeutic Approaches for Treatment of NF1-Associated Tumors.
details: NF1-deficient iHSCs formed tumors with 50% penetrance in athymic nude mice, while NF1-proficient lines never formed tumors
contextSnippet: Tumor formation was never observed for the NF1-proficient cell lines. In contrast, all NF1-deficient lines showed the ability to form tumors upon xenograft, with 50% penetrance

_publicationTitle: Pharmacogenomic Synthetic Lethal Screens Reveal Hidden Vulnerabilities and New Therapeutic Approaches for Treatment of NF1-Associated Tumors.
details: Digoxin showed >1 log shift in IC50 concentration against S462-TY compared to NF1-proficient iHSCs, with near doubling of potency
contextSnippet: When digoxin was used against NF1-deficient iHSCs, a shift of more than 1 log was seen in the IC50 concentration when comparing the MPNST cell line S462-TY with NF1-proficient iHSCs, with a near doubling of potency

_publicationTitle: Pharmacogenomic Synthetic Lethal Screens Reveal Hidden Vulnerabilities and New Therapeutic Approaches for Treatment of NF1-Associated Tumors.
details: Rigosertib showed IC50 concentration in nmol/L range for S462-TY cells but was ineffective against NF1-proficient iHSCs
contextSnippet: Rigosertib showed an IC50 concentration in the nmol/L range for S462-TY cells but was ineffective against NF1-proficient iHSCs

_publicationTitle: Pharmacogenomic Synthetic Lethal Screens Reveal Hidden Vulnerabilities and New Therapeutic Approaches for Treatment of NF1-Associated Tumors.
details: S462-TY cells showed limited sensitivity to MEK inhibition, with 125 μmol/L selumetinib resulting in ~65% cells in S-phase at 24 hours
contextSnippet: S462-TY MPNST cells show limited sensitivity to MEK inhibition. At 24 hours, 125 µmol/L selumetinib alone results in ∼65% of the cells showing an accumulation in the S-phase

_publicationTitle: Pharmacogenomic Synthetic Lethal Screens Reveal Hidden Vulnerabilities and New Therapeutic Approaches for Treatment of NF1-Associated Tumors.
details: Treatment with selumetinib alone for 24 hours resulted in significant feedback activation of RAS pathway as detected by RAS-GTP levels
contextSnippet: Treatment of S462-TY cells with selumetinib alone for 24 hours resulted in significant (P < 0.0001) feedback activation of the RAS pathway as detected by RAS–GTP levels

_publicationTitle: Pharmacogenomic Synthetic Lethal Screens Reveal Hidden Vulnerabilities and New Therapeutic Approaches for Treatment of NF1-Associated Tumors.
details: NF1-deficient iHSCs formed tumors with 50% penetrance in athymic nude mice over 16 weeks, while NF1-proficient lines never formed tumors
contextSnippet: Each line was injected into the flanks of four mice and monitored for signs of tumor formation for 16 weeks. Tumor formation was never observed for the NF1-proficient cell lines. In contrast, all NF1-deficient lines showed the ability to form tumors upon xenograft, with 50% penetrance

_publicationTitle: Pharmacogenomic Synthetic Lethal Screens Reveal Hidden Vulnerabilities and New Therapeutic Approaches for Treatment of NF1-Associated Tumors.
resourceName: NOD-Rag1 null IL2rg null, NOD rag gamma, NOD-RG (NRG) mice (RRID: JAX:007799)
details: NF1-deficient iHSCs developed tumors with 100% penetrance in NRG mice
contextSnippet: When the same lines were tested in the less stringent NRG mouse strain, the NF1-deficient lines developed tumors with 100% penetrance

_publicationTitle: Pharmacogenomic Synthetic Lethal Screens Reveal Hidden Vulnerabilities and New Therapeutic Approaches for Treatment of NF1-Associated Tumors.
resourceName: NOD-Rag1 null IL2rg null, NOD rag gamma, NOD-RG (NRG) mice (RRID: JAX:007799)
details: S462-TY xenograft tumors progressed rapidly from ~200 mm³ to 2,000 mm³ endpoint in about a week in vehicle-treated mice
contextSnippet: Tumors in vehicle-treated mice progressed rapidly after reaching the study size enrollment of ∼200 mm3, with tumors reaching endpoint size criteria of 2,000 mm3 in about a week

_publicationTitle: Pharmacogenomic Synthetic Lethal Screens Reveal Hidden Vulnerabilities and New Therapeutic Approaches for Treatment of NF1-Associated Tumors.
resourceName: NOD-Rag1 null IL2rg null, NOD rag gamma, NOD-RG (NRG) mice (RRID: JAX:007799)
details: Digoxin + selumetinib combination showed dramatic survival improvement with long-term survivors and some animals having no detectable tumors at study conclusion
contextSnippet: Not only did the combination significantly outperform either of the single agents, but we also observed long-term survivors at the conclusion of the study. Some animals had no detectable tumors at the conclusion of the study

_publicationTitle: Pharmacogenomic Synthetic Lethal Screens Reveal Hidden Vulnerabilities and New Therapeutic Approaches for Treatment of NF1-Associated Tumors.
details: Vehicle-treated animals had median survival of 18 days, while single-agent treatments extended survival: rigosertib (22 days), LB100 (24 days), digoxin (27 days), DMAPT (27.5 days), selumetinib (24 days)
contextSnippet: Vehicle-treated animals had a median survival of 18 days, whereas the cohorts treated with rigosertib (22 days), LB100 (24 days), digoxin (27 days), DMAPT (27.5 days), and selumetinib (24 days) showed increased survival

_publicationTitle: Pharmacogenomic Synthetic Lethal Screens Reveal Hidden Vulnerabilities and New Therapeutic Approaches for Treatment of NF1-Associated Tumors.
details: Combination therapies showed dramatic increases in median survival: rigosertib + selumetinib (22 to 47 days) and digoxin + selumetinib (27 to 47.5 days), P < 0.001
contextSnippet: The rigosertib + selumetinib and digoxin + selumetinib combinations each showed dramatic increases in median survival when compared with their single-agent results (22 to 47 days and 27 to 47.5 days, respectively, P < 0.001)

_publicationTitle: Pharmacogenomic Synthetic Lethal Screens Reveal Hidden Vulnerabilities and New Therapeutic Approaches for Treatment of NF1-Associated Tumors.
details: All single agents and combinations were well tolerated with no signs of toxicity including therapy-related lethargy or gastrointestinal issues
contextSnippet: These compounds were well tolerated, with none of the single agents or combinations tested in this model eliciting signs of toxicity in the mice, including therapy-related lethargy or gastrointestinal issues

_publicationTitle: Pharmacogenomic Synthetic Lethal Screens Reveal Hidden Vulnerabilities and New Therapeutic Approaches for Treatment of NF1-Associated Tumors.
details: Selumetinib + digoxin combination showed increase in survival and reduction in tumor growth, though not as robust as in GEMM or cell line xenograft
contextSnippet: We also tested the selumetinib + digoxin combination in an MPNST PDX grown in NRG mice. In the PDX, an increase in survival and reduction in tumor growth was also observed, although it was not as robust as the response seen in the GEMM or MPNST cell line xenograft

_publicationTitle: Pharmacogenomic Synthetic Lethal Screens Reveal Hidden Vulnerabilities and New Therapeutic Approaches for Treatment of NF1-Associated Tumors.
details: Selumetinib + rigosertib combination showed superior tumor growth control compared to monotherapy with corresponding increase in overall survival, and significantly better response than selumetinib + digoxin combination
contextSnippet: when the selumetinib + rigosertib combination was tested in the MPNST PDX mentioned, control of tumor growth was superior to either monotherapy, and there was a corresponding increase in overall survival. The response of this combination in the PDX model was significantly better than the selumetinib + digoxin combination

_publicationTitle: Clinician Perspectives of a Magnetic Resonance Imaging-Based 3D Volumetric Analysis Tool for Neurofibromatosis Type 2-Related Schwannomatosis: Qualitative Pilot Study.
details: Average agreement levels nearing 3.0 (neither disagree nor agree) for statements about 3D volumetric measurements needing visualization (mean 3.07, SD 0.92), 3D models leading to more informed decisions (mean 3.00, SD 1.41), and 3D visualization aiding surgical planning (mean 3.20, SD 1.30)
contextSnippet: Some statements regarding the benefits or potential use of 3D volumetric analysis or 3D visualizations were met with hesitancy, with average agreement levels nearing 3.0 (neither disagree nor agree). These statements claimed that 3D volumetric measurements must be combined with visualization to be clinically meaningful (mean 3.07, SD 0.92), that 3D models of VS tumors would lead to more informed decisions about the type of intervention needed (mean 3.00, SD 1.41) and that 3D visualization of VS tumors in the surrounding cerebral space would aid in surgical planning (mean 3.20, SD 1.30).

_publicationTitle: Clinician Perspectives of a Magnetic Resonance Imaging-Based 3D Volumetric Analysis Tool for Neurofibromatosis Type 2-Related Schwannomatosis: Qualitative Pilot Study.

In Textbox 2 this 'forecasting feature' ranked as the highest priority feature for clinicians

contextSnippet: six genes were significantly associated with Marfan syndrome-specific phenotypes. These include the two previously identified genes, indicating that refining phenotype representation can help uncover additional relevant genes

_publicationTitle: PERADIGM: Phenotype embedding similarity-based rare disease gene mapping.

_publicationTitle: PERADIGM: Phenotype embedding similarity-based rare disease gene mapping.

_publicationTitle: PERADIGM: Phenotype embedding similarity-based rare disease gene mapping.

_publicationTitle: PERADIGM: Phenotype embedding similarity-based rare disease gene mapping.

_publicationTitle: PERADIGM: Phenotype embedding similarity-based rare disease gene mapping.

_publicationTitle: A comprehensive custom panel design for routine hereditary cancer testing: preserving control, improving diagnostics and revealing a complex variation landscape.
details: Analytical sensitivity of 98.4% (96.4-99.4%) and analytical specificity of 100% (99-100%) for detecting known variants in training and validation sets
contextSnippet: Therefore, considering the 358 known variants in the training and validation sets, the analytical sensitivity of the panel was 98.4% (96.4–99.4%) and the analytical specificity was of 100% (99–100%).

_publicationTitle: A comprehensive custom panel design for routine hereditary cancer testing: preserving control, improving diagnostics and revealing a complex variation landscape.
details: Within-run precision (repeatability) of 98% (97-98.7%) and between-run precision (reproducibility) of 95.7% (94.6-96.6%)
contextSnippet: within-run precision (repeatability) was 98% (97–98.7%) and between-run precision (reproducibility) was 95.7% (94.6–96.6%), both within the optimal range for diagnostic purposes

_publicationTitle: A comprehensive custom panel design for routine hereditary cancer testing: preserving control, improving diagnostics and revealing a complex variation landscape.
details: 98.9% ± 0.7% SD of targeted bases covered ≥ 30× with mean depth of coverage 495 ± 170 SD
contextSnippet: More than 98.9% ± 0.7% SD of the targeted bases was covered ≥ 30× (Supplementary Fig S2). Detailed sequencing statistics are given in Supplementary Table S3.

_publicationTitle: A comprehensive custom panel design for routine hereditary cancer testing: preserving control, improving diagnostics and revealing a complex variation landscape.
details: Correctly identified all 36 pathogenic variants in validation set including substitutions, small insertions/deletions (up to 19 bp), and deletions of single exon and whole gene
contextSnippet: This new approach correctly identified all 36 pathogenic variants in the validation set, including substitutions, small insertions/deletions (up to 19 bp), and deletions of a single exon and a whole gene.

_publicationTitle: A comprehensive custom panel design for routine hereditary cancer testing: preserving control, improving diagnostics and revealing a complex variation landscape.
details: Sensitivity of 90.4% (84.2-94.8%) detecting 123 out of 136 pathogenic and non-pathogenic variants, failed to identify 7 out of 23 pathogenic variants mostly in homopolymers
contextSnippet: 123 out of 136 pathogenic and non-pathogenic variants previously identified in the training set were correctly detected, providing a sensitivity of 90.4% (84.2–94.8%). However, this first approach failed to identify 7 out of 23 pathogenic variants

_publicationTitle: A comprehensive custom panel design for routine hereditary cancer testing: preserving control, improving diagnostics and revealing a complex variation landscape.
details: Mean depth of coverage 490.7 ± 221.5 SD with more than 86% ± 4% SD of targeted ROI bases covered ≥ 30x
contextSnippet: the mean depth of coverage was 490.7 ± 221.5 SD, and more than 86% ± 4% SD of the targeted ROI bases was covered ≥ 30x.

_publicationTitle: A comprehensive custom panel design for routine hereditary cancer testing: preserving control, improving diagnostics and revealing a complex variation landscape.
details: Sensitivity of 100% (97.3-100%) for all pathogenic and non-pathogenic variants, correctly identified 22 of 23 pathogenic variants and all 113 non-pathogenic SNVs and indels
contextSnippet: Taking into account all pathogenic and non-pathogenic variants previously identified in the training set, NGS data provided a sensitivity of 100% (97.3–100%).

_publicationTitle: A comprehensive custom panel design for routine hereditary cancer testing: preserving control, improving diagnostics and revealing a complex variation landscape.
details: Specificity of 100% (98.3-100%) with no false positives identified in training set
contextSnippet: Overall, no false positive was identified, resulting in a specificity of 100% (98.3–100%) for the training set.

_publicationTitle: A comprehensive custom panel design for routine hereditary cancer testing: preserving control, improving diagnostics and revealing a complex variation landscape.
details: Used for initial data analysis approach but was replaced by custom NGS pipeline for improved variant calling quality
contextSnippet: Data were analyzed using both CLC Genomics Workbench (Qiagen) and our custom NGS pipeline... we analyzed all data using only our custom NGS pipeline, to ensure greater control over variant calling algorithms

_publicationTitle: Insertional Mutagenesis Identifies a STAT3/Arid1b/β-catenin Pathway Driving Neurofibroma Initiation.

Importantly, 7/9 mice injected with ΔN90 β-catenin infected Stat3 fl/fl;Nf1 fl/fl;DhhCre spheres developed neurofibroma like lesions, while no lesions were detected in vector controls

_publicationTitle: Machine Learning of Allosteric Effects: The Analysis of Ligand-Induced Dynamics to Predict Functional Effects in TRAP1.

contextSnippet: ML models were built to ensure learning of inhibitor-bound patterns from the allosteric ligands expected to have the biggest detectable impact on TRAP1 local unperturbed dynamics.

_publicationTitle: Machine Learning of Allosteric Effects: The Analysis of Ligand-Induced Dynamics to Predict Functional Effects in TRAP1.
details: Used for analysis of MD trajectories to extract local features including residue-level solvation, contacts, and distances from flexible regions of TRAP1 monomers
contextSnippet: We focused on residue-level solvation, contacts, and distances obtained from four inherently flexible regions of the buckled and straight monomers

_publicationTitle: Machine Learning of Allosteric Effects: The Analysis of Ligand-Induced Dynamics to Predict Functional Effects in TRAP1.

contextSnippet: The average accuracy in each validation fold varies between 66.7 and 94.9%, with the discriminative models outperforming the generative ones

_publicationTitle: Machine Learning of Allosteric Effects: The Analysis of Ligand-Induced Dynamics to Predict Functional Effects in TRAP1.

contextSnippet: 68–69% of inhibitor-free trajectories can be genuinely recovered as TN. For NB models, the loss in specificity is lower, in the range of 2–23%

_publicationTitle: Machine Learning of Allosteric Effects: The Analysis of Ligand-Induced Dynamics to Predict Functional Effects in TRAP1.

contextSnippet: showing a significant r² value of 0.71 for the KNB model... ML-based classification of inhibitors from MD simulations outperform docking-based models

contextSnippet: Nf1 9a−/9a− mice showed a significant deficit in TBS-induced LTP. Consistent with the sensitivity of TBS-induced LTP to changes in GABAergic inhibition, LTP was normal when induced using a high-frequency stimulation (HFS) protocol

details: Showed increased inhibitory postsynaptic potential amplitude at higher stimulus levels and reduced paired-pulse ratio, suggesting enhanced GABA release
contextSnippet: inhibitory postsynaptic potential amplitude was bigger at higher stimulus levels in Nf1 9a−/9a− mice, whereas paired-pulse ratio was reduced, suggesting a change in presynaptic GABA release

_publicationTitle: HCN channels are a novel therapeutic target for cognitive dysfunction in Neurofibromatosis type 1.
details: PV neurons showed 7 mV hyperpolarizing shift in I_h half-activation potential (-88.4 ± 1.9 mV vs -81.2 ± 2.0 mV in WT)
contextSnippet: Fits of the activation curve with a Boltzmann function yielded a hyperpolarizing shift of 7 mV in the half-activation potential (V1/2) in Nf1 9a−/9a− mice (-88.4 ± 1.9 mV, n = 10) compared with their WT littermates (-81.2 ± 2.0 mV, n = 7, P < 0.01)

_publicationTitle: HCN channels are a novel therapeutic target for cognitive dysfunction in Neurofibromatosis type 1.
details: PV neurons had hyperpolarized resting membrane potential (-64.1 ± 0.7 mV vs -60.6 ± 0.7 mV) and higher input resistance (279 ± 19 MΩ vs 235 ± 14 MΩ)
contextSnippet: PV neurons of Nf1 9a−/9a− mice had a significantly hyperpolarized resting membrane potential (-64.1 ± 0.7 mV, n = 17 vs -60.6 ± 0.7 mV, n = 12; P < 0.005) and a higher input resistance (279 ± 19 MΩ, n = 15 vs 235 ± 14 MΩ, n = 16, P < 0.05)

_publicationTitle: HCN channels are a novel therapeutic target for cognitive dysfunction in Neurofibromatosis type 1.
details: At 50 μM, increased I_h magnitude and caused significant depolarizing shift in activation, fully normalizing V1/2 to -80.9 ± 2.0 mV in Nf1 PV neurons
contextSnippet: LTG increased the magnitude of Ih in Nf1 9a−/9a− mice and caused a significant depolarizing shift in Ih activation in Nf1 9a−/9a− PV neurons, which was fully normalized compared with recordings from WT mice. The V1/2 in the presence of LTG was −80.9 ± 2.0 mV (n = 9)

_publicationTitle: HCN channels are a novel therapeutic target for cognitive dysfunction in Neurofibromatosis type 1.
details: Caused reduction of action potential firing rates in Nf1 PV neurons, with effect blocked by prior HCN antagonist ZD7288 application
contextSnippet: bath application of LTG caused a reduction of action potential firing rates in response to depolarizing current injections in Nf1 9a−/9a− mice. To determine whether the effect of LTG on membrane excitability was directly mediated via Ih, the HCN antagonist ZD7288 was applied before application of LTG. In this condition, the effect of LTG on membrane excitability was fully blocked

_publicationTitle: HCN channels are a novel therapeutic target for cognitive dysfunction in Neurofibromatosis type 1.
details: Restored LTP in Nf1 mice to the level of WT mice at Schaffer collateral-CA1 synapses
contextSnippet: LTG restored LTP in Nf1 9a−/9a− mice to the level of WT mice, whereas the LTP deficit remained evident in vehicle-treated slices from Nf1 9a−/9a− mice

_publicationTitle: HCN channels are a novel therapeutic target for cognitive dysfunction in Neurofibromatosis type 1.
details: At 25 mg/kg i.p., restored spatial learning capacity in Nf1 9a−/9a− mice, showing clear preference for target quadrant in Morris water maze
contextSnippet: LTG treatment restored the learning capacity of Nf1 9a−/9a− mice, without altering the performance of their WT littermates. Furthermore, and consistent with a prominent influence of HCN channel function in the pathophysiology of the Nf1+/− mouse model, Nf1+/− mice treated with LTG also showed a clear preference for the target quadrant

_publicationTitle: HCN channels are a novel therapeutic target for cognitive dysfunction in Neurofibromatosis type 1.
details: Successfully detected spatial learning impairments in both Nf1 9a−/9a− and Nf1+/− mice, with deficits rescued by lamotrigine treatment
contextSnippet: Nf1 9a−/9a− mice were tested in the Morris water maze task previously demonstrated to be impaired in Nf1+/− mice. Indeed, Nf1 9a−/9a− mice utilized an exclusively non-spatial search strategy and showed no preference for the target quadrant

_publicationTitle: HCN channels are a novel therapeutic target for cognitive dysfunction in Neurofibromatosis type 1.
details: Detected motor coordination deficits in Nf1+/− mice that were completely rescued by lamotrigine treatment
contextSnippet: Nf1+/− mice showed impaired learning on the accelerating rotarod, a motor learning paradigm that does not depend on hippocampal function. Indeed, LTG treatment completely rescued the motor coordination deficit in Nf1+/− mice

_publicationTitle: HCN channels are a novel therapeutic target for cognitive dysfunction in Neurofibromatosis type 1.
details: Showed dramatic increase in Ras-ERK pathway with phosphorylated ERK1 at 212% of WT and ERK2 at 246% of WT in hippocampus
contextSnippet: H-RasG12V mice showed a dramatic increase of the Ras-ERK pathway, as measured by the relative level of phosphorylated ERK1 (212% of WT, P < 0.01) and ERK2 (246% of WT, P < 0.001) in the hippocampus

_publicationTitle: HCN channels are a novel therapeutic target for cognitive dysfunction in Neurofibromatosis type 1.
details: Despite marked ERK activation, showed no alterations in I_h current-voltage relationship, voltage dependence, or PV neuron excitability compared to WT
contextSnippet: in contrast to Nf1 mutant mice, the current–voltage relationship and voltage dependence of Ih in PV neurons were similar between H-RasG12V and WT littermates. Furthermore, the slope of activation and the Ih kinetics remained intact. Consistent with the absence of any detectable changes in Ih, neither the resting membrane potential nor the input resistance was altered in H-RasG12V PV neurons

_publicationTitle: FAP expression as a marker of malignant transformation enabling in vivo characterization in peripheral nerve sheath tumors: a multimodal and translational study.
details: Confirmed inter- and intra-tumoral heterogeneity of FAP expression in MPNST tumor cells, consistent with spatial and scRNA data findings
contextSnippet: IHC confirmed the inter- and intra-tumoral heterogeneity of FAP expression in MPNST tumor cells, which we also observed in spatial and scRNA data

_publicationTitle: FAP expression as a marker of malignant transformation enabling in vivo characterization in peripheral nerve sheath tumors: a multimodal and translational study.
details: Low-level cross-reactivity observed in eccrine sweat glands, likely due to structural similarity between FAP and DPP4 (51.9% sequence identity)
contextSnippet: We observed almost no relevant immunoreactivity in neurofibromas and uninvolved healthy tissue...except of eccrine sweat glands, which are known to express dipeptidyl peptidase IV (DPP4)...BLAST alignment revealed 51.9% sequence identify

_publicationTitle: FAP expression as a marker of malignant transformation enabling in vivo characterization in peripheral nerve sheath tumors: a multimodal and translational study.
details: MPNST on left forearm showed high FAP expression uptake (SUVmax 14.7) while adjacent neurofibroma showed lower uptake (SUVmax 3.5), with histopathological confirmation of strong FAP expression in MPNST and no FAP expression in neurofibroma
contextSnippet: the MPNST on the left forearm shows high [18F]FDG uptake (a) and high FAP expression (b) (SUVmax 10.7 vs. 14.7)...whereas the MPNST lesion on the left forearm consisted of a hyper-cellular tumor...with strong cytoplasmic and membranous FAP expression

_publicationTitle: FAP expression as a marker of malignant transformation enabling in vivo characterization in peripheral nerve sheath tumors: a multimodal and translational study.
details: One neurofibroma at sciatic nerve showed moderate, patchy tracer uptake (SUVmax FAP: 9.5) but lacked detectable FAP protein expression on immunohistochemistry, suggesting possible stromal remodeling or sampling limitations
contextSnippet: one neurofibroma located at the sciatic nerve, that exhibited moderate, patchy tracer uptake, lacked any detectable FAP protein expression in immunohistochemistry. This discrepancy and the patchy tracer accumulation in PET imaging may reflect localized stromal remodeling

_publicationTitle: FAP expression as a marker of malignant transformation enabling in vivo characterization in peripheral nerve sheath tumors: a multimodal and translational study.
details: Used to quantify FAP expression differences between tumor types, showing MPNSTs had significantly higher H-scores than neurofibromas in both tumor and stromal compartments (both p < 0.001)
contextSnippet: H scores for immuno-histochemical FAP expression in MPNSTs (n = 12), conventional neurofibromas (n = 12)...MPNSTs exhibited significantly higher FAP expression compared to neurofibromas in stromal as well as tumor cells (both p < 0.001)

_publicationTitle: Quality of life in patients with neurofibromatosis type 1 and 2 in Canada.
details: NF1 and NF2 patients had significantly lower scores in all domains compared to Canadian normative population (P < 0.005)
contextSnippet: Patients with NF1 and NF2 had significantly lower scores in all the domains in the SF-36 compared to the Canadian normative population at this age range (t test P < .005)

_publicationTitle: Quality of life in patients with neurofibromatosis type 1 and 2 in Canada.
details: NF2 patients had significantly lower Social Functioning and General Health scores than NF1 patients (P-values 0.02 and 0.016, respectively)
contextSnippet: NF2 patients had lower scores than patients with NF1, although this difference was only significant for Social Functioning and General Health (P-values .02 and .016, respectively)

_publicationTitle: Quality of life in patients with neurofibromatosis type 1 and 2 in Canada.
details: High proportion of patients reported pain/discomfort (66% NF1, 73% NF2) and anxiety/depression (61% NF1, 68% NF2)
contextSnippet: we found that a high proportion of patients reported some degree of pain/discomfort (66% for NF1 and 73% NF2, respectively) and anxiety/depression (61% and 68% for NF1 and NF2, respectively)

_publicationTitle: Quality of life in patients with neurofibromatosis type 1 and 2 in Canada.
details: Mean VAS score was 74.5 ± 23 for NF1 and 64.2 ± 21 for NF2 (P = 0.05); mean health utility score was 0.73 ± 0.24 for NF1 and 0.65 ± 0.25 for NF2 (P = 0.16)
contextSnippet: The mean EQ-5D-5L VAS score was 74.5 ± 23 for NF1 patients and 64.2 ± 21 for NF2 (P-value .05). The mean EQ-5D-5L health utility score was 0.73 ± 0.24 for NF1 and 0.65 ± 0.25 for NF2 patients (P-value .16)

_publicationTitle: Quality of life in patients with neurofibromatosis type 1 and 2 in Canada.
details: Cronbach's alpha was 0.96; domains with lowest scores (worse QoL) were perceived physical appearance, worry, cognitive, emotion, fatigue, and pain
contextSnippet: Cronbach's alpha for the PedsQL NF1 was 0.96. The PedsQL NF1 domains with the lowest scores (worse QoL) were perceived physical appearance, worry, cognitive, emotion, fatigue, and pain

_publicationTitle: Quality of life in patients with neurofibromatosis type 1 and 2 in Canada.
details: Cronbach's alpha was 0.87; items with highest (worse) scores were hearing (median 2, range 1-3) and outlook on life (median 2, range 0-3)
contextSnippet: Cronbach's alpha was 0.87. The items with highest (worse) scores were hearing (median 2, range 1–3) and outlook on life (median 2, range 0–3)

_publicationTitle: Quality of life in patients with neurofibromatosis type 1 and 2 in Canada.
details: High correlations with EQ-5D-5L utility score (r: -0.76, P < 0.001), EQ-5D-5L VAS score (r: -0.52, P = 0.01), SF-36 PCS (r: -0.65, P = 0.003), and SF-36 MCS (r: -0.63, P = 0.004)
contextSnippet: The total NFTI-QoL had moderate to high correlations with the EQ-5D-5L utility score (r: −0.76, CI: −0.89, −0.49, P < .001), the EQ-5D-5L VAS score (r: −0.52, CI: −0.77, −0.11, P = .01), SF-36 PCS (r: −0.65, CI: −0.86, −0.26, P = .003), and the SF-36 MCS (r: −0.63, CI: −0.85, −0.23, P = .004)

_publicationTitle: Quality of life in patients with neurofibromatosis type 1 and 2 in Canada.
details: High correlations with health utilities: -0.70 for NF1 (P < 0.001) and -0.90 for NF2 (P < 0.001)
contextSnippet: the correlation between pain interference and health utilities was −0.70 (CI: −0.77, −0.61, P < .001) for NF1 and −0.90 (CI: −0.96, −0.78, P < .001) for NF2

_publicationTitle: Quality of life in patients with neurofibromatosis type 1 and 2 in Canada.
details: Pain interference was significantly associated with worse SF-36 PCS (estimate -0.68, P < 0.0001) and was main driver of QoL for both NF1 and NF2
contextSnippet: Worse pain interference scores and older age were significantly associated with worse SF-36 PCS... pain interference was the main driver of QoL both for NF1 and NF2, demonstrated by the high correlations between pain interference and QoL scales

_publicationTitle: Quality of life in patients with neurofibromatosis type 1 and 2 in Canada.
details: No correlation found with mental health when rated by examiner, unlike self-reported physical appearance measures
contextSnippet: when we looked at the Ablon index—rated by an examiner—we did not find a correlation with mental health; however, when we used self-reported physical appearance, it became a major driver of mental health related QoL

_publicationTitle: Quality of life in patients with neurofibromatosis type 1 and 2 in Canada.
resourceName: House and Brackmann facial nerve scale
details: Grade 1: 14 patients (63%), Grades 2-3: 5 patients (23%), Grades 5-6: 3 patients (14%) in NF2 cohort
contextSnippet: Facial nerve scale Grade 1 NA 14 (63%) Grades 2 and 3 NA 5 (23%) Grades 5 and 6 NA 3 (14%)

_publicationTitle: Integration of single-nuclei RNA-sequencing, spatial transcriptomics and histochemistry defines the complex microenvironment of NF1-associated plexiform neurofibromas.
details: Successfully captured approximately 4,000 nuclei per sample across 8 PN patient samples, providing adequate coverage for cellular heterogeneity analysis
contextSnippet: Single-nuclei RNA-sequencing (snRNA-seq) was performed on 8 bulk frozen PN patient samples capturing approximately 4,000 nuclei per sample, a sufficient number of nuclei to provide adequate coverage

_publicationTitle: Integration of single-nuclei RNA-sequencing, spatial transcriptomics and histochemistry defines the complex microenvironment of NF1-associated plexiform neurofibromas.
details: Successfully aligned and projected 26,734 nuclei from 8 PN patient samples revealing complex cellular microenvironment with high inter-sample homogeneity
contextSnippet: Harmony UMAP projection of single-nuclei expression data of 8 PN patient samples on 26,734 nuclei reveals a complex cellular microenvironment...despite being resected from a variety of anatomical locations

_publicationTitle: Integration of single-nuclei RNA-sequencing, spatial transcriptomics and histochemistry defines the complex microenvironment of NF1-associated plexiform neurofibromas.
details: ST spots spanned 55 µM equating to approximately 8 to 12 cells per spot, with spots spaced 100 µM apart across 4 frozen primary PN samples
contextSnippet: ST spots spanned 55 µM which equated to approximately 8 to 12 cells per spot...Spots are spaced 100 µM apart

_publicationTitle: Integration of single-nuclei RNA-sequencing, spatial transcriptomics and histochemistry defines the complex microenvironment of NF1-associated plexiform neurofibromas.
details: Successfully processed sequencing data from 8550 spots in 4 PN samples and identified 15 conserved spot clusters using Seurat with Harmony alignment
contextSnippet: Sequencing data from 8550 spots in 4 PN samples was aggregated and processed to identify 15 conserved spot clusters using Seurat with Harmony alignment

_publicationTitle: Integration of single-nuclei RNA-sequencing, spatial transcriptomics and histochemistry defines the complex microenvironment of NF1-associated plexiform neurofibromas.
details: Identified strong probability of NLGN1-NRXN1 binding between fibroblast subpopulations and NM-SCs, with highest probability between endoneurial/perineurial fibroblasts and NM-SC-1 (probability = 0.346 and 0.341 respectively, p < 0.0001)
contextSnippet: A strong probability of binding of Neuroligan 1 (NLGN1) to Neurexin 1 (NRXN1)...with the highest probability of interaction between endoneurial and perineurial fibroblast-associated NLGN1 and NM-SC-1 associated-NRXN1 (probability of interaction = 0.346 and 0.341 respectively, p < 0.0001 for both)

_publicationTitle: Integration of single-nuclei RNA-sequencing, spatial transcriptomics and histochemistry defines the complex microenvironment of NF1-associated plexiform neurofibromas.
details: Successfully validated endoneurial fibroblast marker expression primarily in endoneurium of oversized nerve fascicles with no staining outside fascicles, confirming snRNA-seq data
contextSnippet: By IHC LAMA2 was seen to be expressed primarily in the endoneurium of the oversized nerve fascicles with staining spread into the perineurial zone...Importantly, there was no LAMA2 staining outside of the oversized nerve fascicles

_publicationTitle: Integration of single-nuclei RNA-sequencing, spatial transcriptomics and histochemistry defines the complex microenvironment of NF1-associated plexiform neurofibromas.
details: Successfully validated perineurial fibroblast marker with cytoplasmic staining predominantly in thin perineurial fibroblast layer, recapitulating snRNA-seq expression profiles
contextSnippet: SLC22A3 acts as a polyspecific organic cation transporter, and by IHC its cytoplasmic staining was predominately seen in the thin perineurial fibroblast layer...once again recapitulating SLC22A3 expression profiles in our snRNA-seq data

_publicationTitle: Integration of single-nuclei RNA-sequencing, spatial transcriptomics and histochemistry defines the complex microenvironment of NF1-associated plexiform neurofibromas.
details: Successfully validated epineurial fibroblast marker with expression predominantly in epineurial zones surrounding nerve fascicles, confirming snRNA-seq data
contextSnippet: Indeed, PRRX1 is expressed predominantly in the epineurial zones surrounding the nerve fascicles

_publicationTitle: Integration of single-nuclei RNA-sequencing, spatial transcriptomics and histochemistry defines the complex microenvironment of NF1-associated plexiform neurofibromas.
details: Successfully identified NM-SC with clear nuclear staining both within endoneurium and scattered throughout epineurial zones, revealing Schwann cell infiltration outside normal fascicle boundaries
contextSnippet: We see clear nuclear SOX10 staining NM-SC contained exclusively inside of the endoneurium...SOX10 positive NM-SC existing in epineurial zones...SOX10 NM-SC were not only found in the endoneurium but also scattered throughout the epineurial zones

_publicationTitle: Exhaustive non-synonymous variants functionality prediction enables high resolution characterization of the neurofibromin architecture.

contextSnippet: In order to train our own prediction model, we used as input the scores provided by each prediction tool, together with various other annotations... The model demonstrated a significantly higher AUC value than the tool with the highest AUC (0.946; P < 0.05).

_publicationTitle: Exhaustive non-synonymous variants functionality prediction enables high resolution characterization of the neurofibromin architecture.

contextSnippet: radiation-exposure reduced the overall survival of Nf1+/− mice in a dose-dependent manner (log-rank test p<0.0001, Figure 1B) at higher dose levels (15 and 30 Gy). The median survivals of Nf1+/− mice receiving 0, 3, 15, and 30 Gy were 583, 652, 469 and 410 days, respectively.

_publicationTitle: Genetically mediated Nf1 loss in mice promotes diverse radiation-induced tumors modeling second malignant neoplasms.
details: Tumor incidence increased with increasing radiation dose (p < 0.0001 by χ2 analysis), demonstrating enhanced radiation-induced tumorigenesis compared to wildtype mice
contextSnippet: Tumors were more common in Nf1+/− mice than WT mice, and for Nf1+/− mice tumor incidence increased with increasing radiation dose (p < 0.0001 by χ2 analysis, Figure 2)

_publicationTitle: Genetically mediated Nf1 loss in mice promotes diverse radiation-induced tumors modeling second malignant neoplasms.
details: Sarcomas were significantly more common in irradiated Nf1+/- mice than irradiated wildtype mice (p = 0.0175, log-rank)
contextSnippet: sarcomas are well recognized SMNs after high-dose radiation therapy (21–23), and were significantly more common in irradiated Nf1+/− mice than irradiated WT mice (p = 0.0175, log-rank)

_publicationTitle: Genetically mediated Nf1 loss in mice promotes diverse radiation-induced tumors modeling second malignant neoplasms.
details: Solid tumor free survival and hematologic disease free survival were both reduced in a dose-dependent manner (log rank test, p<0.0001 for solid tumor free survival and p=0.0001 for hematologic disease free survival)
contextSnippet: solid tumor free survival and hematologic disease free survival were both reduced in a dose-dependent manner in Nf1+/− mice but not WT mice (Figure 3, log rank test, p<0.0001 for solid tumor free survival in Nf1+/− mice and p=0.0001 for hematologic disease free survival in Nf1+/− mice)

_publicationTitle: Genetically mediated Nf1 loss in mice promotes diverse radiation-induced tumors modeling second malignant neoplasms.

_publicationTitle: Genetically mediated Nf1 loss in mice promotes diverse radiation-induced tumors modeling second malignant neoplasms.

_publicationTitle: Proof of Concept for Genome Profiling of the Neurofibroma/Sarcoma Sequence in Neurofibromatosis Type 1.
details: Identified 67 CNVs in primary tumor, 233 CNVs in lung metastasis, and 243 CNVs in skin metastasis
contextSnippet: Finally, we used Varsome Clinical software (v12.3.2) to identify CNVs. The primary tumor exhibits a total of 67 CNVs, dissimilar metastases, which show 233 and 243 CNVs, respectively.

_publicationTitle: Proof of Concept for Genome Profiling of the Neurofibroma/Sarcoma Sequence in Neurofibromatosis Type 1.
details: Successfully performed CNV calling and revealed greater genomic instability in metastases with log2 ratio values of about 3 and -3

_publicationTitle: Proof of Concept for Genome Profiling of the Neurofibroma/Sarcoma Sequence in Neurofibromatosis Type 1.
details: Kaplan-Meier analysis identified 6 genes (RBMX, PNPLA6, C1S, LAMB3, SMC1A, PLOD2) associated with lower and significant patient survival in sarcoma samples
contextSnippet: Using The Cancer Genome Atlas (TCGA) database related to sarcoma samples (SARC), accessible via the GEPIA portal...we observed that a change in expression of RBMX, PNPLA6, C1S, LAMB3, SMC1A and PLOD2 was associated with lower and significant patient survival

_publicationTitle: Proof of Concept for Genome Profiling of the Neurofibroma/Sarcoma Sequence in Neurofibromatosis Type 1.
details: Analysis of metastatic samples identified 4 genes (AGAP2, VSIG8, RBMX, PRSS2) associated with reduced overall survival in lung and skin cancer datasets
contextSnippet: For the metastatic samples, we chose to perform Kaplan–Meier analysis on common genes...Out of 14 common genes, only expression changes in AGAP2, VSIG8, RBMX and PRSS2 were associated with reduced overall survival

_publicationTitle: Proof of Concept for Genome Profiling of the Neurofibroma/Sarcoma Sequence in Neurofibromatosis Type 1.
details: Successfully performed pathway analysis identifying statistically significant GO terms, KEGG pathways, and Reactome pathways associated with cell motility, division, signaling and metabolism for primary tumor
contextSnippet: To define a biological significance of the candidate genes, we performed a pathway analysis using the information available in the Gene Ontology (GO), Kyoto Encyclopedia of Genes and Genomes (KEGG) pathway and Reactome databases, obtaining statistically significant results only for the primary tumor gene list.

_publicationTitle: Identifying Symptoms of Distress in Youth Living with Neurofibromatosis Type 1 (NF1).

contextSnippet: Caregiver/patient and provider/patient concordance were both quite poor. Only one age group (13–17 year olds) exhibited a significant, but modest, correlation in reported distress levels between the caregivers and their child (r = 0.41, p < 0.05).

_publicationTitle: Selective nitration of Hsp90 acts as a metabolic switch promoting tumor cell proliferation.
resourceName: normal human Schwann cells (Cat. No. 1700, ScienCell Research Laboratories)
details: Intracellular delivery of nitrated Hsp90 forms (NO2Hsp90, Hsp90NY33, Hsp90NY56) significantly increased proliferation ~20% at 48h compared to unmodified Hsp90
contextSnippet: Intracellular delivery of NO2Hsp90, Hsp90NY33, or Hsp90NY56 significantly increased Schwann cell proliferation compared to the delivery of Hsp90 both 24 h (Figs. 3B) and 48 h post-delivery

_publicationTitle: Selective nitration of Hsp90 acts as a metabolic switch promoting tumor cell proliferation.
resourceName: normal human Schwann cells (Cat. No. 1700, ScienCell Research Laboratories)
details: NO2Hsp90 delivery decreased basal and ATP-linked mitochondrial respiration compared to Hsp90 delivery
contextSnippet: Intracellular delivery of NO2Hsp90 decreased basal and ATP-linked respiration compared to intracellular delivery of Hsp90

_publicationTitle: Selective nitration of Hsp90 acts as a metabolic switch promoting tumor cell proliferation.
resourceName: normal human Schwann cells (Cat. No. 1700, ScienCell Research Laboratories)
details: Hsp90NY56 increased glycolysis compared to Hsp90 delivery, recapitulating metabolic effects observed in schwannoma cells
contextSnippet: In parallel to the glycolytic effect observed in schwannoma cells, Hsp90NY56 increased glycolysis compared to the delivery of Hsp90

_publicationTitle: Selective nitration of Hsp90 acts as a metabolic switch promoting tumor cell proliferation.
details: Doubling endogenous nitrated Hsp90 levels induced statistically significant increase in cell growth 24h post-delivery, with ~15-20% increase in proliferation
contextSnippet: Doubling the levels of NO2Hsp90 induced a statistically significant increase in cell growth 24 h post-delivery...similar to the ~15–20% increase observed in schwannoma cell proliferation

_publicationTitle: Selective nitration of Hsp90 acts as a metabolic switch promoting tumor cell proliferation.
details: NO2Hsp90 delivery significantly decreased basal and ATP-linked respiration, increased proton leak, and decreased maximal respiration compared to Hsp90
contextSnippet: Intracellular delivery of NO2Hsp90 significantly decreased basal and ATP-linked respiration, increased proton leak, and decreased maximal respiration as compared to the delivery of Hsp90

_publicationTitle: Selective nitration of Hsp90 acts as a metabolic switch promoting tumor cell proliferation.
details: Hsp90NY56 increased glycolysis while Hsp90NY33 decreased mitochondrial activity, with proliferative effects abrogated by P2X7R inhibitor KN62
contextSnippet: Only NO2Hsp90 and Hsp90NY56 increased glycolysis...Incubation with KN62 (10 μM) for 24 h...abrogated the proliferative effect in both schwannoma cells

_publicationTitle: Selective nitration of Hsp90 acts as a metabolic switch promoting tumor cell proliferation.
details: Successfully delivered recombinant nitrated Hsp90 proteins intracellularly, with delivered protein detectable 48h post-delivery in normal Schwann cells
contextSnippet: we optimized the intracellular delivery protocol to introduce similar levels of recombinant NO2Hsp90 into schwannoma cells...we were able to detect the delivered recombinant protein 48 h after intracellular delivery

_publicationTitle: Selective nitration of Hsp90 acts as a metabolic switch promoting tumor cell proliferation.
details: Successfully measured oxygen consumption rate (OCR) and extracellular acidification rate (ECAR) to assess mitochondrial activity and glycolysis in response to nitrated Hsp90 delivery
contextSnippet: Using extracellular flux analysis, we found that doubling the intracellular levels of nitrated Hsp90 decreased all mitochondrial parameters, determined by assessing the oxygen consumption rate (OCR)

_publicationTitle: Selective nitration of Hsp90 acts as a metabolic switch promoting tumor cell proliferation.

contextSnippet: Hsp90 nitrated on Y56 (Hsp90NY56) represented 7.9 ± 1.9 % of total Hsp90 in NF2-SWN vestibular schwannomas (VS; Fig. 1B), and 11.4 ± 3.0 % in schwannoma cells in culture

_publicationTitle: Selective nitration of Hsp90 acts as a metabolic switch promoting tumor cell proliferation.

contextSnippet: In cell clusters, Hsp90NY33 localized in the periphery, in the outer cellular layer, correlating with the proliferation marker Ki67, whereas Hsp90NY56 was found homogenously distributed throughout the cell clusters

_publicationTitle: Phase II trial of pirfenidone in children and young adults with neurofibromatosis type 1 and progressive plexiform neurofibromas.

contextSnippet: The most frequent pirfenidone related toxicities were nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea (Table II). Only three patients required a dose reduction for pirfenidone related toxicities consisting of: (1) recurrent grade 2 neutropenia in cycle 39, (2) grade 3 nausea in cycle 1, and (3) grade 3 neutropenia in cycle 1.

_publicationTitle: Real-time PCR analysis of candidate imprinted genes on mouse chromosome 11 shows balanced expression from the maternal and paternal chromosomes and strain-specific variation in expression levels.
details: Higher brain cancer susceptibility compared to 129 strain, with Nf1 expression 30% higher in B6 brains than 129 brains
contextSnippet: We have previously shown using quantitative PCR and SYBR green detection methods that the level of expression of Nf1 in wild-type B6 brains is 30% higher than wild-type 129 brains.

_publicationTitle: Real-time PCR analysis of candidate imprinted genes on mouse chromosome 11 shows balanced expression from the maternal and paternal chromosomes and strain-specific variation in expression levels.

_publicationTitle: Longitudinal phenotype development in a minipig model of neurofibromatosis type 1.
details: Model develops 5 key NF1 phenotypic characteristics: CALMs, axillary/inguinal freckling, shortened stature, tibial bone curvature, and histological variations in neurofibroma growth
contextSnippet: Through systematic tracking we have shown that an NF1+/ex42del minipig model develops phenotypic characteristics [1] CALMs, [2] axillary/inguinal freckling, [3] shortened stature, [4] tibial bone curvature, and [5] histological variations in neurofibroma growth.

_publicationTitle: Longitudinal phenotype development in a minipig model of neurofibromatosis type 1.
details: Statistically smaller long bones (femur, tibia, humerus, ulna, metacarpals) in NF1 minipigs compared to wildtype siblings, indicating short stature phenotype
contextSnippet: We found statistically smaller long bones (femur, tibia, humerus, ulna, metacarpals) in the NF1+/ex42del minipigs compared to their wildtype siblings.

_publicationTitle: Longitudinal phenotype development in a minipig model of neurofibromatosis type 1.
details: CALMs in minipigs range from 1.0 cm to 5.0 cm in diameter, similar to human presentation (0.5 cm to >20 cm)
contextSnippet: Over 99% of humans with NF1 present with CALMs ranging from 0.5 cm to greater than 20 cm in diameter. Here, through longitudinal tracking of CALMs we found the minipig presentation showed similarity in size (1.0 cm–5.0 cm).

_publicationTitle: Longitudinal phenotype development in a minipig model of neurofibromatosis type 1.

contextSnippet: One out of eight NF1+/ex42del animals developed a neurofibroma which progressed over time, paralleled to imaging characteristics of human neurofibromas, and demonstrated differential maturation on histopathology.

_publicationTitle: Longitudinal phenotype development in a minipig model of neurofibromatosis type 1.

contextSnippet: Weight was not statistically significantly different between NF1+/ex42del and wildtype minipigs at any of the three study time points (4, 8 and 12 months of age).

_publicationTitle: Longitudinal phenotype development in a minipig model of neurofibromatosis type 1.

contextSnippet: In our cohort of 8 NF1+/ex42del minipigs we did not see indication of optic glioma or optic chiasm tumor...Measurement of the optic nerve and sheath indicated no significant difference (p > 0.19) between NF1+/ex42del and wildtype

_publicationTitle: Longitudinal phenotype development in a minipig model of neurofibromatosis type 1.

contextSnippet: We demonstrated detection of neurofibroma with LDCT and with additional testing this could suggest LDCT as a viable option for whole-body screening with reduced radiation exposure over standard CT, and as a fast acquisition (not requiring anesthesia) alternative to MR.

contextSnippet: We recorded the development and growth of a neurofibroma in a minipig model over the course over a 20-month period with four imaging time-points consisting of screening MR, targeted MR, and whole-body CT.

contextSnippet: We performed an extensive CT-based skeletal measurement assessment in our matched cohort.
